description: GNS3 is a free graphical network simulator capable of emulating a number of network devices. This makes it possible for anyone to quickly and easily spin up network hardware for testing and educational purposes without the heavy expense of physical hardware. Supported devices include Cisco routers and firewalls, Juniper routers, and frame-relay switches.
name: GNS3
subtitle: Router emulation software

episodes.title: What is GNS3?
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,374
[NOISE] We get a lot of questions at

2
00:00:05,374 --> 00:00:11,119
ITProTV about how best to study for

3
00:00:11,119 --> 00:00:14,099
the Cisco exams.

4
00:00:14,099 --> 00:00:19,291
If you're working on your CCNA, CCNP,
even your CCIE, those certifications,

5
00:00:19,291 --> 00:00:23,375
they really require hands on
experience with Cisco equipment.

6
00:00:23,375 --> 00:00:25,240
What if you don't have
that available though?

7
00:00:25,240 --> 00:00:29,032
Well there's a really neat product
out there that can help with that and

8
00:00:29,032 --> 00:00:30,178
it's called GNS3.

9
00:00:30,178 --> 00:00:32,980
One of the nice thing about
GNS3 is it is completely free.

10
00:00:32,980 --> 00:00:35,920
It doesn't cost you any money,
so why not use it?

11
00:00:35,920 --> 00:00:38,532
So this series of videos
that we're going to film,

12
00:00:38,532 --> 00:00:42,537
they're gonna show you what GNS3 is,
how it works, how to use it and be able to

13
00:00:42,537 --> 00:00:46,760
build up a lab environment to study and
practice to get ready for your exams.

14
00:00:46,760 --> 00:00:49,821
It's really neat stuff and
it's really not that hard to get set up.

15
00:00:50,890 --> 00:00:53,800
Let's start off real high level though,
what is GNS3?

16
00:00:54,870 --> 00:00:59,420
Deep down inside of it at its heart,
GNS3 is really just a graphically user

17
00:00:59,420 --> 00:01:03,625
interface for
another product called Dynamips.

18
00:01:03,625 --> 00:01:07,100
Dynamips is the actual heart and
soul of this product.

19
00:01:07,100 --> 00:01:11,707
What it is, is years ago, it's a long
time, a good eight to ten years ago,

20
00:01:11,707 --> 00:01:16,650
someone sat down and they wrote
a hardware emulator for Cisco equipment.

21
00:01:16,650 --> 00:01:20,050
If you crack open your average Cisco
router, you'll find that they have

22
00:01:20,050 --> 00:01:25,308
Intel processors and RAM and standard
components like what you'd find in a PC.

23
00:01:25,308 --> 00:01:27,470
Granted it's a proprietary motherboard but

24
00:01:27,470 --> 00:01:30,950
the majority of the components
are just standard components.

25
00:01:30,950 --> 00:01:34,830
So, they wrote this emulator to
emulate that set of hardware so

26
00:01:34,830 --> 00:01:40,180
you could run the actual Cisco IOS,
on this emulated platform.

27
00:01:40,180 --> 00:01:43,980
Well, Dynamips did a pretty good job,
but it was command line only,

28
00:01:43,980 --> 00:01:45,850
so it wasn't very user-friendly.

29
00:01:45,850 --> 00:01:50,711
So the GNS3 project was started to
create a graphical user interface for

30
00:01:50,711 --> 00:01:52,313
the Dynamips utility.

31
00:01:52,313 --> 00:01:54,754
And it's still Dynamips is under the hood,
but

32
00:01:54,754 --> 00:01:57,696
the graphical user interface
kind of covers all that up.

33
00:01:57,696 --> 00:02:00,755
And so a lot of people look at GNS3
as being a full total product, and

34
00:02:00,755 --> 00:02:04,310
it's actually made up of
several different components.

35
00:02:04,310 --> 00:02:06,160
But, you don't have to worry about that.

36
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:09,990
We can download and install GNS3,
have it up and running, and

37
00:02:09,990 --> 00:02:12,670
start emulating Cisco hardware.

38
00:02:12,670 --> 00:02:15,890
Now, notice I'm saying emulate,
not simulate.

39
00:02:15,890 --> 00:02:19,340
There's a lot of companies out there that
do simulators, like the Boson NetiSm.

40
00:02:19,340 --> 00:02:20,770
And they're perfectly good products.

41
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:24,458
But on those, you're not actually
working with the Cisco IOS.

42
00:02:24,458 --> 00:02:27,620
You're usually interacting with
something like a Java application.

43
00:02:27,620 --> 00:02:30,180
You type a command,
it parses your command, and

44
00:02:30,180 --> 00:02:33,230
it gives you canned output
that reflects what you typed.

45
00:02:33,230 --> 00:02:36,950
So when you type show version, it's not
actually checking what IOS version you're

46
00:02:36,950 --> 00:02:38,000
running and displaying that.

47
00:02:38,000 --> 00:02:40,680
Instead it's got this canned
output that it feeds you.

48
00:02:40,680 --> 00:02:42,470
The problem with simulators,

49
00:02:42,470 --> 00:02:45,860
they only support the commands
that the developers put in there.

50
00:02:45,860 --> 00:02:49,270
So if you wanna run a command that's
outside of the scope of the CCNA course,

51
00:02:49,270 --> 00:02:51,160
for example, it's not gonna work.

52
00:02:51,160 --> 00:02:52,790
Right?
Now I say that's the problem.

53
00:02:52,790 --> 00:02:53,720
It's not really a problem.

54
00:02:53,720 --> 00:02:56,460
If you're studying for the exam,
those simulators are great.

55
00:02:56,460 --> 00:03:00,420
They usually come prepackaged with labs,
and they're a really valuable resource.

56
00:03:00,420 --> 00:03:01,849
I've used the Boson NetSim myself.

57
00:03:01,849 --> 00:03:03,276
I really like the product.

58
00:03:03,276 --> 00:03:08,589
But an emulator, with an emulator,
you run the actual Cisco IOS.

59
00:03:08,589 --> 00:03:09,910
Every command works.

60
00:03:09,910 --> 00:03:13,130
Doesn't matter if it's on the exam or
not, all the commands work.

61
00:03:13,130 --> 00:03:16,382
And it's the real IOS so
it's not like you're running a command and

62
00:03:16,382 --> 00:03:17,533
you get canned output.

63
00:03:17,533 --> 00:03:21,970
You get output that's reflecting what's
going on in that router at that time.

64
00:03:21,970 --> 00:03:24,723
So, there's the real value of an emulator.

65
00:03:24,723 --> 00:03:28,584
You can use GNS3 to study to get ready for
the exams, you can use it to mock up

66
00:03:28,584 --> 00:03:32,240
networks to get ready for
some kind of deployment in production.

67
00:03:32,240 --> 00:03:34,456
You can do all sorts of
really cool things in it.

68
00:03:34,456 --> 00:03:35,453
It's a neat product, and

69
00:03:35,453 --> 00:03:37,640
the fact that it's free is
really just icing on the cake.

70
00:03:37,640 --> 00:03:40,018
All right,
if you've never heard of it before,

71
00:03:40,018 --> 00:03:41,824
the website is really easy to get to.

72
00:03:41,824 --> 00:03:47,524
It's GNS3.net, and so
that's where I'm at right now is GNS3.net.

73
00:03:47,524 --> 00:03:49,365
Their web page is fairly Spartan.

74
00:03:49,365 --> 00:03:51,087
Not a whole lot of stuff on here, and

75
00:03:51,087 --> 00:03:54,010
it really centers around
getting you that software.

76
00:03:54,010 --> 00:03:57,223
They give a description here and
they tell you it's an intuitive

77
00:03:57,223 --> 00:04:00,628
graphical user interface and
it runs on top of multiple emulators.

78
00:04:00,628 --> 00:04:02,200
Dynamips is the main one.

79
00:04:02,200 --> 00:04:04,360
That's the Cisco IOS emulator.

80
00:04:04,360 --> 00:04:05,292
But it does more.

81
00:04:05,292 --> 00:04:09,759
You'll see there's a VirtualBox and
a QEMU emulator too.

82
00:04:09,759 --> 00:04:11,176
Why do we need those?

83
00:04:11,176 --> 00:04:15,339
Well, you'll see that it adds Cisco ASA
and Pix support, so if you want to

84
00:04:15,339 --> 00:04:19,930
do Cisco firewalls, it also allows
you to do things like Juniper, Junos.

85
00:04:19,930 --> 00:04:22,582
If you wanna learn Juniper routers,
you can bring those up.

86
00:04:22,582 --> 00:04:26,029
But they run on different types of
hardware than what Cisco routers do, so

87
00:04:26,029 --> 00:04:27,590
they don't use Dynamips.

88
00:04:27,590 --> 00:04:31,470
They use VirtualBox and QEMU to
emulate the hardware needed for them.

89
00:04:31,470 --> 00:04:32,248
It's a little bit different.

90
00:04:32,248 --> 00:04:33,940
Now you can do it all at once though.

91
00:04:33,940 --> 00:04:38,493
So you could have Cisco IOS routers
running by the Cisco ASA, running right by

92
00:04:38,493 --> 00:04:43,627
a Junos router, you know you can have that
flexibility, it's really, really cool.

93
00:04:43,627 --> 00:04:48,280
Now, one of the main questions that you'll
see asked on the Internet on these various

94
00:04:48,280 --> 00:04:49,910
questions is.

95
00:04:49,910 --> 00:04:51,773
Is this legal?

96
00:04:51,773 --> 00:04:56,830
Well, you know, as like many of these
things there's kind of a grey area here.

97
00:04:56,830 --> 00:05:00,686
The true honest answer at the end of
the day is that yes, it is legal.

98
00:05:00,686 --> 00:05:03,800
The emulator itself is legal,
the software is legal.

99
00:05:03,800 --> 00:05:07,292
Where we start to get into
a problem is with the IOS, right.

100
00:05:07,292 --> 00:05:10,270
Cisco routers run the Internetwork
Operating System, the IOS.

101
00:05:10,270 --> 00:05:12,525
And when you buy a Cisco router.

102
00:05:12,525 --> 00:05:19,140
You're also buying a license to run
the IOS on that router hardware.

103
00:05:19,140 --> 00:05:21,430
That means, you've licensed the IOS but

104
00:05:21,430 --> 00:05:24,188
you've only licensed it
to run on that hardware.

105
00:05:24,188 --> 00:05:26,742
You're not licensed to
run it somewhere else.

106
00:05:26,742 --> 00:05:29,547
Cisco doesn't sell just licenses for
the IOS.

107
00:05:29,547 --> 00:05:33,220
They only sell licenses for
the IOS tied to hardware.

108
00:05:33,220 --> 00:05:37,160
So when we fire up something like GNS3
it's gonna need the operating system,

109
00:05:37,160 --> 00:05:38,390
it's gonna need the IOS.

110
00:05:38,390 --> 00:05:40,300
They don't give us that cuz
they're not allowed to.

111
00:05:40,300 --> 00:05:41,980
That would be illegal.

112
00:05:41,980 --> 00:05:45,660
But if you have a copy of the IOS
from your own production routers,

113
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:48,770
you can throw it on here and
it'll run just fine.

114
00:05:48,770 --> 00:05:50,930
But technically you're
violating your license,

115
00:05:50,930 --> 00:05:53,551
cuz your license said you were
licensed to run that software.

116
00:05:53,551 --> 00:05:58,032
On top of the Cisco hardware, not on
top of GNS3 or Dynamips or whatever,

117
00:05:58,032 --> 00:05:59,270
all right.

118
00:05:59,270 --> 00:06:01,039
So is it legal?

119
00:06:01,039 --> 00:06:03,419
Well the software is.

120
00:06:03,419 --> 00:06:06,838
Using it though requires you to pull
a Cisco license the wrong way which is

121
00:06:06,838 --> 00:06:08,420
technically not legal, right.

122
00:06:08,420 --> 00:06:10,979
You're violating the terms
of service from Cisco.

123
00:06:10,979 --> 00:06:15,160
That being said,
even Cisco uses GNS3 internally.

124
00:06:15,160 --> 00:06:17,846
So it's a very common, popular program.

125
00:06:17,846 --> 00:06:22,298
There's a lot of companies out there that
do Cisco training and they use GNS3.

126
00:06:22,298 --> 00:06:25,001
So, it's something that's
definitely known by Cisco and

127
00:06:25,001 --> 00:06:27,120
they've chosen not to
enforce that license.

128
00:06:27,120 --> 00:06:30,349
Now, one day they may change their mind,
but as of right now,

129
00:06:30,349 --> 00:06:32,417
they haven't enforced that license.

130
00:06:32,417 --> 00:06:35,842
And so many, many people,
including myself make use of the product.

131
00:06:35,842 --> 00:06:38,315
So it is a really neat one.

132
00:06:38,315 --> 00:06:42,492
Well if you want to see just kind of
a quick guided tour of it before we get it

133
00:06:42,492 --> 00:06:46,970
installed, they've got some nice
screenshots here on the website.

134
00:06:46,970 --> 00:06:50,747
And what it does is it gives you
this graphical user interface,

135
00:06:50,747 --> 00:06:52,042
this guy right here.

136
00:06:52,042 --> 00:06:55,854
The way it works is basically you have
all of these routers, firewalls, Juniper

137
00:06:55,854 --> 00:07:00,540
routers, all of these things over her on
the left; this is your network equipment.

138
00:07:00,540 --> 00:07:04,570
You just drag and drop it out here and
you link it together.

139
00:07:04,570 --> 00:07:08,350
You can link it together with
ethernet cables or serial cables,

140
00:07:08,350 --> 00:07:09,780
that's what these red
lightning bolts are here.

141
00:07:09,780 --> 00:07:10,965
These are serial cables.

142
00:07:10,965 --> 00:07:15,830
They're doing simulated T1 lines or
ISDN, or something like that.

143
00:07:15,830 --> 00:07:19,830
You can emulate technology that would be
incredibly expensive to set up in your own

144
00:07:19,830 --> 00:07:23,570
lab, and you can bring out
as many routers as you want.

145
00:07:23,570 --> 00:07:27,435
So instead of having to go to eBay and buy
a bunch of physical used routers that may

146
00:07:27,435 --> 00:07:30,339
or may not work right, here,
you just bring them right up.

147
00:07:30,339 --> 00:07:34,516
And you'll see the routers that they
support, the 1700s, those are pretty

148
00:07:34,516 --> 00:07:38,600
low-end, pretty old routers, but
they go up all the way to the 7200s.

149
00:07:38,600 --> 00:07:43,438
And the Cisco 7200, that's a beefy
router that can perform every

150
00:07:43,438 --> 00:07:47,298
single activity from the CCNA,
CCNP, and CCIE exams.

151
00:07:47,298 --> 00:07:50,435
It's a really,
really powerful router framework, so

152
00:07:50,435 --> 00:07:53,020
you really get that full feature set.

153
00:07:53,020 --> 00:07:55,008
And they don't show it
here in this screen shot,

154
00:07:55,008 --> 00:07:56,668
let me see if they have one that shows it.

155
00:07:56,668 --> 00:08:00,640
When you add a router in, you can pull
up the properties of that router and

156
00:08:00,640 --> 00:08:02,660
start to manipulate its settings.

157
00:08:02,660 --> 00:08:04,473
And, yeah they don't really show it here.

158
00:08:04,473 --> 00:08:07,571
But you can manipulate the settings
as far as inserting different WICs,

159
00:08:07,571 --> 00:08:08,700
the WAN interface cards.

160
00:08:08,700 --> 00:08:11,102
You can choose which cards you want in it,

161
00:08:11,102 --> 00:08:14,409
to make that router unique for
that particular purpose.

162
00:08:14,409 --> 00:08:16,790
You know like these routers here.

163
00:08:16,790 --> 00:08:19,758
Cisco routers don't typically come
with serial ports by default.

164
00:08:19,758 --> 00:08:23,019
So somebody's added cards into these
routers to be able to have that

165
00:08:23,019 --> 00:08:24,450
connectivity.

166
00:08:24,450 --> 00:08:25,446
You get link lights and

167
00:08:25,446 --> 00:08:28,395
information as far as whether
the connections are up and working.

168
00:08:28,395 --> 00:08:30,530
And you can start and stop the routers.

169
00:08:30,530 --> 00:08:34,363
You can back up their configurations and
build some really cool labs.

170
00:08:34,363 --> 00:08:36,880
They even have some labs available for
download on their site.

171
00:08:36,880 --> 00:08:39,010
If you look up here,
we've got this labs tab and

172
00:08:39,010 --> 00:08:42,336
you'll see here some, it looks like
they just have the Juniper ones now.

173
00:08:42,336 --> 00:08:43,760
But they're working on Cisco ones.

174
00:08:43,760 --> 00:08:46,028
I know those are coming out soon.

175
00:08:46,028 --> 00:08:48,960
But, actually that's what
they're saying right here.

176
00:08:48,960 --> 00:08:51,245
Labs will come very soon for Cisco.

177
00:08:51,245 --> 00:08:53,750
But basically it's a very
valuable resource, and

178
00:08:53,750 --> 00:08:57,370
it's a great alternative to going out and
buying the physical hardware.

179
00:08:57,370 --> 00:08:59,292
Now, can you buy the physical hardware?

180
00:08:59,292 --> 00:08:59,906
Absolutely.

181
00:08:59,906 --> 00:09:01,277
That's what I did when I got started.

182
00:09:01,277 --> 00:09:02,840
I went out and ordered eight routers.

183
00:09:02,840 --> 00:09:05,755
It cost me a ton of money,
and they were super loud and

184
00:09:05,755 --> 00:09:08,021
ate up a lot of electricity at the house.

185
00:09:08,021 --> 00:09:10,130
But that's how I learned,
over ten years ago.

186
00:09:10,130 --> 00:09:10,660
Right.

187
00:09:10,660 --> 00:09:12,093
Because we didn't have things like this.

188
00:09:12,093 --> 00:09:15,400
If I had to do it again today, I never
would've bought all that equipment, right.

189
00:09:15,400 --> 00:09:17,443
It was a lot of money
kinda down the drain.

190
00:09:17,443 --> 00:09:21,293
Versus this, where I could whip up
whatever environment I wanted and when I

191
00:09:21,293 --> 00:09:25,344
was done I could just shut it down and
it's not consuming extra power and so on.

192
00:09:25,344 --> 00:09:29,204
The other thing is it's really efficient,
we'll see this a little bit later, how it

193
00:09:29,204 --> 00:09:32,890
manages CPU and how it manages memory,
it does a really good job on those things.

194
00:09:32,890 --> 00:09:38,449
So GS3, very powerful software package,
does a lot of great things.

195
00:09:38,449 --> 00:09:39,925
Wonderful for your studies.

196
00:09:39,925 --> 00:09:43,452
All right,
that's enough of an introduction for GNS3.

197
00:09:43,452 --> 00:09:46,746
Now we're going to move into our next set
of videos, where we'll start to show how

198
00:09:46,746 --> 00:09:48,916
to get it installed and
how to actually make use of it.

199
00:09:48,916 --> 00:09:50,354
So, stay tuned.

200
00:09:50,354 --> 00:09:52,375
We'll be back with more.

201
00:09:52,375 --> 00:09:58,049
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Installing GNS3
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,012 --> 00:00:07,713
[SOUND]
So

2
00:00:07,713 --> 00:00:12,390
now we’re ready to get GNS3 installed,
and it’s really pretty easy.

3
00:00:12,390 --> 00:00:15,480
When you install GNS3,
the first part is we need to go in and

4
00:00:15,480 --> 00:00:19,210
download our binaries, right,
download the software to get it installed.

5
00:00:19,210 --> 00:00:23,030
And GNS3 is available for
more than one operating system.

6
00:00:23,030 --> 00:00:24,970
So you’ll see a couple
of different choices.

7
00:00:24,970 --> 00:00:26,790
If you're running OS X, that's fine.

8
00:00:26,790 --> 00:00:27,300
They support it.

9
00:00:27,300 --> 00:00:28,590
If you're running Windows, it's there.

10
00:00:28,590 --> 00:00:30,140
If you're running Linux, it's there.

11
00:00:30,140 --> 00:00:32,670
It's all developed using Python and Qt and

12
00:00:32,670 --> 00:00:38,590
that means it is really platform agnostic,
it's really, really quite neat.

13
00:00:38,590 --> 00:00:43,580
If you wanna download it, jump over to
the gns3.net page, and let me warn you.

14
00:00:43,580 --> 00:00:45,950
They do display a lot of
advertisements on the page.

15
00:00:45,950 --> 00:00:47,160
Remember, this is free software.

16
00:00:47,160 --> 00:00:48,820
They gotta make money somehow.

17
00:00:48,820 --> 00:00:52,460
But, there's been more than once when I
have come to there page and the ad said,

18
00:00:52,460 --> 00:00:54,100
you know like it had a big
download button, and

19
00:00:54,100 --> 00:00:58,480
it looked like that was the way to go and
in reality that was just an advertisement.

20
00:00:58,480 --> 00:01:00,200
So you do want to be careful with that.

21
00:01:00,200 --> 00:01:03,770
Don't just jump in and
hit Download on the first button you see.

22
00:01:03,770 --> 00:01:07,250
Right up here in their menu bar though,
you'll see a link that says, Download.

23
00:01:07,250 --> 00:01:08,540
And we can go and hit that and

24
00:01:08,540 --> 00:01:10,840
it'll take us to the various
download links that we've got.

25
00:01:10,840 --> 00:01:13,170
And you need to pick the one for
your operating system.

26
00:01:13,170 --> 00:01:14,870
You'll see Windows,

27
00:01:14,870 --> 00:01:19,750
Mac, OS X, Linux and just the generic
source code down there at the bottom.

28
00:01:19,750 --> 00:01:21,900
So, we picked the one that we want.

29
00:01:21,900 --> 00:01:26,430
For windows we are normally gonna
use this GNS3 all in one, all right?

30
00:01:26,430 --> 00:01:31,050
But for 32 and 64 bit system you can
pick and choose if you want, but

31
00:01:31,050 --> 00:01:34,520
if you get the all in one, its actually
got both in the same package and

32
00:01:34,520 --> 00:01:37,206
it will choose the appropriate one for
your system.

33
00:01:37,206 --> 00:01:40,810
For Mac OS X, you'll see that they've
got their current version and

34
00:01:40,810 --> 00:01:42,690
their older Snow Leopard version.

35
00:01:42,690 --> 00:01:46,680
On the Linux side they've got packages for
Debian and Ubuntu.

36
00:01:46,680 --> 00:01:50,400
They don't have like Red Hat packages,
but you can bring those in.

37
00:01:50,400 --> 00:01:52,810
There's a few different
ways to go about that.

38
00:01:52,810 --> 00:01:53,550
All right.

39
00:01:53,550 --> 00:01:55,550
So, these are the different
packages that are available.

40
00:01:55,550 --> 00:01:57,520
We just download it and get it installed.

41
00:01:57,520 --> 00:02:01,160
Now, notice it's packaged
with a lot of other things.

42
00:02:01,160 --> 00:02:04,600
It says it includes dynamips,
QEMU, and PEMU.

43
00:02:04,600 --> 00:02:09,150
I've mentioned each of those,
it also includes PuTTY.

44
00:02:09,150 --> 00:02:13,840
Now, PuTTY is a Telnet,
SSH and serial port client.

45
00:02:13,840 --> 00:02:15,655
I use it in a lot of our shows.

46
00:02:15,655 --> 00:02:17,960
You'll see, I've already got it
installed on my machine, right here.

47
00:02:17,960 --> 00:02:20,850
So, it's my go to SSH client.

48
00:02:20,850 --> 00:02:25,125
And, in a really handy way,
to be able to quickly connect to systems.

49
00:02:25,125 --> 00:02:27,130
GNS3 has it packaged in, so

50
00:02:27,130 --> 00:02:30,110
that you can connect to the routers
that are in your system.

51
00:02:30,110 --> 00:02:32,950
You'll see VPCS and Win Pcap.

52
00:02:32,950 --> 00:02:35,870
Each of these are providing different
functionality in the system.

53
00:02:35,870 --> 00:02:37,780
Win Pcap is one of the most important.

54
00:02:37,780 --> 00:02:43,300
Now Win Pcap is part of the Windows
installer, not Mac OS X, and not Linux.

55
00:02:43,300 --> 00:02:51,000
What WinPcap is a packet capture driver
sorry, packet capture driver I can say it.

56
00:02:51,000 --> 00:02:56,080
In Windows, software is not allowed
to just grab a network card and

57
00:02:56,080 --> 00:02:58,710
flip it into what's called promiscuous
mode where it just starts gathering all

58
00:02:58,710 --> 00:02:59,840
the data that it sees.

59
00:02:59,840 --> 00:03:01,370
Windows doesn't allow that.

60
00:03:01,370 --> 00:03:03,830
WINPcap enables that,
it enables the ability for

61
00:03:03,830 --> 00:03:07,550
all our software to just gather all
the data off of a network card.

62
00:03:07,550 --> 00:03:12,770
Inside of GNS3, if we want to be able to
monitor the traffic on these routers,

63
00:03:12,770 --> 00:03:14,260
we need that functionality.

64
00:03:14,260 --> 00:03:16,450
Now you may already have
WINPcap on your system,

65
00:03:16,450 --> 00:03:19,150
other software like
Wireshark installs it too.

66
00:03:19,150 --> 00:03:20,710
So, you very well may already have it.

67
00:03:20,710 --> 00:03:22,660
But if you don't, it is packaged in there.

68
00:03:22,660 --> 00:03:25,890
And you'll even see here,
Wireshark is packaged in.

69
00:03:25,890 --> 00:03:26,470
Why is that?

70
00:03:26,470 --> 00:03:28,570
Well, you might have
noticed in the screenshots,

71
00:03:28,570 --> 00:03:33,050
they give us the ability to right
click on a link, right here.

72
00:03:33,050 --> 00:03:37,580
When you're inside of GNS3, you can
right click on a link anywhere you want.

73
00:03:37,580 --> 00:03:41,110
And choose Capture Network and
it will launch Wireshark and

74
00:03:41,110 --> 00:03:44,330
it'll show you the actual packets
that are crossing that line so

75
00:03:44,330 --> 00:03:46,040
you can see the traffic in real time.

76
00:03:46,040 --> 00:03:48,810
It's really neat, so
they package Wireshark with it.

77
00:03:48,810 --> 00:03:51,830
Now if you already have WinPcap installed
or if you already have Wireshark,

78
00:03:51,830 --> 00:03:54,830
it's not gonna double them up on you,
right, but if you're missing them it will

79
00:03:54,830 --> 00:03:57,900
put them on there, so that's kind
of a neat I think that it does.

80
00:03:59,200 --> 00:04:01,820
All right, so
let's get this turkey installed.

81
00:04:01,820 --> 00:04:04,800
When we download it,
it's just a straight forward installer,

82
00:04:04,800 --> 00:04:06,390
nothing too special there.

83
00:04:06,390 --> 00:04:10,670
Looks like it's asking me to sign up for
updates.

84
00:04:10,670 --> 00:04:13,220
Notice this tiny little link down here,
no thanks,

85
00:04:13,220 --> 00:04:15,995
please take me to the download,
that's what I want.

86
00:04:15,995 --> 00:04:18,120
[LAUGH] All right, so
I'm going to go and download it and

87
00:04:18,120 --> 00:04:20,090
this download is coming from SourceForge.

88
00:04:20,090 --> 00:04:22,730
SourceForge you can
trust most of the time.

89
00:04:22,730 --> 00:04:24,650
Sometimes SourceForge does weird stuff.

90
00:04:24,650 --> 00:04:26,160
But I'm gonna go ahead and download this.

91
00:04:26,160 --> 00:04:30,080
I'll just store it right on my desktop and
we'll download that.

92
00:04:30,080 --> 00:04:31,320
It's about 40MB in size.

93
00:04:31,320 --> 00:04:32,350
Not very big.

94
00:04:32,350 --> 00:04:34,630
We'll see it gets bigger as we
start to throw all of our different

95
00:04:34,630 --> 00:04:35,750
software in there.

96
00:04:35,750 --> 00:04:36,750
So we'll get that download.

97
00:04:36,750 --> 00:04:38,740
Now during the installer,

98
00:04:38,740 --> 00:04:42,160
for the most part we're just gonna
be clicking Next a bunch of times.

99
00:04:42,160 --> 00:04:46,400
But when it gets to installing WinPcap,
it's gonna reset my network adapter.

100
00:04:46,400 --> 00:04:49,930
Now I'm sharing my screen with
you guys via our network here so

101
00:04:49,930 --> 00:04:53,400
when my network adapter resets,
my screen will probably freeze.

102
00:04:53,400 --> 00:04:54,850
So just expect that.

103
00:04:54,850 --> 00:04:57,700
In real life land, if you're
installing this in the background, and

104
00:04:57,700 --> 00:05:01,860
you're doing work on your computer,
your work might get interrupted.

105
00:05:01,860 --> 00:05:03,329
So before installing GNS3,

106
00:05:03,329 --> 00:05:06,450
make sure you finished anything
you were doing on the network.

107
00:05:06,450 --> 00:05:09,250
Just anticipate those
network adapters to reset.

108
00:05:09,250 --> 00:05:12,970
Same thing with Linux and Mac OS X,

109
00:05:12,970 --> 00:05:14,770
on those guys you don't
have to install Win PCap.

110
00:05:14,770 --> 00:05:16,280
They already have the packet drivers.

111
00:05:16,280 --> 00:05:18,620
They use Lid PCap or something like that.

112
00:05:18,620 --> 00:05:21,760
And so they've already got that
functionality but it'll still reset your

113
00:05:21,760 --> 00:05:24,750
adapters when it gets set up so
you'll see that little interruption.

114
00:05:25,780 --> 00:05:29,900
All right, so mine finished downloading,
I can see it right here on my desktop, and

115
00:05:29,900 --> 00:05:33,020
I'm just gonna run through that installer,
all right.

116
00:05:33,020 --> 00:05:34,770
For the most part we're
clicking Next a bunch,

117
00:05:34,770 --> 00:05:36,840
you're just picking
a directory to install.

118
00:05:36,840 --> 00:05:39,540
But WinPcap is gonna install
as a separate installer,

119
00:05:39,540 --> 00:05:42,740
so at one point it's gonna lauch
another installation window for me.

120
00:05:44,130 --> 00:05:45,260
So I'll just start moving through this.

121
00:05:45,260 --> 00:05:48,880
So I'm gonna agree to my little license
agreements and I'll pick the Start Menu

122
00:05:48,880 --> 00:05:53,190
folder, and here we see all the different
components it's gonna install.

123
00:05:53,190 --> 00:05:57,920
Now, if I know that I'm not gonna be using
some of these things, I can go in and

124
00:05:57,920 --> 00:05:58,670
uncheck them.

125
00:05:58,670 --> 00:06:04,260
If I know I'm not gonna use QEMU and PEMU,
I'm just not gonna do Juniper or whatever.

126
00:06:04,260 --> 00:06:07,880
I might choose to uncheck those so I don't
have them, and it gives you a little

127
00:06:07,880 --> 00:06:12,800
description of each one, like VPCS, that's
a virtual PC simulator, it's useful for

128
00:06:12,800 --> 00:06:17,050
having nodes,
like computers to test pinging from.

129
00:06:17,050 --> 00:06:19,420
It runs, I think it actually runs OpenDos,

130
00:06:19,420 --> 00:06:23,135
just a very simple install to let
you test network connectivity, but

131
00:06:23,135 --> 00:06:26,608
you'll see the other things in here,
GNS3 being the main one.

132
00:06:26,608 --> 00:06:30,332
Notice how Super PuTTY is listed and
it's unchecked, and

133
00:06:30,332 --> 00:06:34,650
that's because it saw that I
already have PuTTY on my system.

134
00:06:34,650 --> 00:06:37,670
I might want to choose to install that
one anyway, I can check it off and

135
00:06:37,670 --> 00:06:39,220
then we would have that too,
so I'll do it.

136
00:06:41,930 --> 00:06:44,800
All right, it's gonna install in SQL and
/Program Files/GNS3.

137
00:06:44,800 --> 00:06:48,460
I'm on a 64-bit version of Windows.

138
00:06:48,460 --> 00:06:52,083
So if it was installing the 32 bit
version, it would've pointed to SQL and

139
00:06:52,083 --> 00:06:53,540
/Program Files x86.

140
00:06:53,540 --> 00:06:56,760
So I know that it properly chose
the 64 bit version for me.

141
00:06:58,520 --> 00:07:00,250
And I’ll hit Install.

142
00:07:00,250 --> 00:07:02,890
Here’s where it launches
a second installer.

143
00:07:02,890 --> 00:07:06,410
So, my GNS3 installer is still sitting
back here, but here’s WinPcap now.

144
00:07:06,410 --> 00:07:09,740
So I’ve gotta get it installed,
and so I’ll move forward on that.

145
00:07:09,740 --> 00:07:13,430
Now, this is the part where
we may see this freeze.

146
00:07:13,430 --> 00:07:14,650
Now, it does ask us one thing here.

147
00:07:14,650 --> 00:07:18,620
It says, do we want to automatically
start WinPcap at boot time.

148
00:07:18,620 --> 00:07:22,928
All right, if you're gonna use GNS3 a lot,
using it every day whatever, then yeah,

149
00:07:22,928 --> 00:07:25,938
you probably want WinPcap to
start when your system boots and

150
00:07:25,938 --> 00:07:28,050
just have it always available.

151
00:07:28,050 --> 00:07:33,142
But if you're using GNS3 every now and
then, you might want to turn this off and

152
00:07:33,142 --> 00:07:38,082
when you're going to use GNS3 you would
just go into your services screen and

153
00:07:38,082 --> 00:07:39,914
start the WinPcap service.

154
00:07:39,914 --> 00:07:43,570
Run GNS3, when you're done,
you stop the WinPcap service.

155
00:07:43,570 --> 00:07:45,390
You start and stop it when you need it.

156
00:07:45,390 --> 00:07:48,280
I normally use it a lot cuz it's all
tied to Wireshark so I'll go ahead and

157
00:07:48,280 --> 00:07:49,450
let it start at boot time.

158
00:07:51,020 --> 00:07:51,760
All right.

159
00:07:51,760 --> 00:07:55,070
So there's it's gonna install and
it looks like,

160
00:07:55,070 --> 00:07:57,740
remarkably I didn't loose my connection.

161
00:07:57,740 --> 00:08:01,470
Oh, I did get an error though,
error downloading Wireshark.

162
00:08:01,470 --> 00:08:02,359
Well, that's different.

163
00:08:04,200 --> 00:08:08,030
Let it try again, all right, so
now it's kinda turning through,

164
00:08:08,030 --> 00:08:10,870
here it's downloading the SolarWinds
response time viewer, so

165
00:08:10,870 --> 00:08:15,390
a little free product form SolarWinds
to be able to monitor traffic there.

166
00:08:15,390 --> 00:08:18,870
So it's just installing that,
oh they want me to register,

167
00:08:18,870 --> 00:08:21,010
I'm gonna cancel that
cuz I don't really care.

168
00:08:21,010 --> 00:08:23,313
There we go.
[LAUGH] You know, SolarWinds,

169
00:08:23,313 --> 00:08:24,980
they're a great company.

170
00:08:24,980 --> 00:08:26,700
They have a lot of great products.

171
00:08:26,700 --> 00:08:29,840
But once you're on their mailing list,
you're on it forever.

172
00:08:29,840 --> 00:08:31,120
You'll get a ton of emails from them.

173
00:08:31,120 --> 00:08:35,060
So I usually don't register with them.

174
00:08:35,060 --> 00:08:36,900
All right, so,
there's my installation finishing.

175
00:08:36,900 --> 00:08:38,160
I'll go ahead and move forward.

176
00:08:38,160 --> 00:08:39,000
It's also asking for

177
00:08:39,000 --> 00:08:41,990
that email address again, if you
want to get their training material.

178
00:08:41,990 --> 00:08:43,325
I'm not going to do that,
I'll just hit Next.

179
00:08:46,763 --> 00:08:48,520
All right, and then we can finish up.

180
00:08:48,520 --> 00:08:51,760
Now we did get an error when it said
it was trying to download GNS3 so

181
00:08:51,760 --> 00:08:54,330
I might get a problem here with my
launch but we'll see what happens.

182
00:08:56,220 --> 00:08:56,930
And there we go.

183
00:08:56,930 --> 00:09:00,430
So, it launched the web page but
here's GNS3 itself.

184
00:09:00,430 --> 00:09:02,940
It's installed and it's up and
running, all right.

185
00:09:02,940 --> 00:09:05,580
Now what we're seeing here
is the initial Setup Wizard.

186
00:09:05,580 --> 00:09:09,640
We've gotta few more steps to go through
before the system is actually useful.

187
00:09:09,640 --> 00:09:14,570
But if I just get rid of that, here it is,
GNS3 installed and ready to rock.

188
00:09:14,570 --> 00:09:18,030
Now, it looks a little different than
those screenshots I showed you earlier.

189
00:09:18,030 --> 00:09:20,440
And that's because they're
constantly updating GNS3.

190
00:09:20,440 --> 00:09:23,200
They're not constantly
updating their website.

191
00:09:23,200 --> 00:09:25,160
So, expect some little differences.

192
00:09:25,160 --> 00:09:27,360
I've got these nice big
icons over here now,

193
00:09:27,360 --> 00:09:30,170
as opposed to the older smaller icons.

194
00:09:30,170 --> 00:09:33,840
It's just the way they've changed it to
make a little more room on the screen,

195
00:09:33,840 --> 00:09:37,280
so just keep in mind that things might be
a little different when you get in there.

196
00:09:37,280 --> 00:09:40,140
All right, well this is a pretty
good spot for us to stop here.

197
00:09:40,140 --> 00:09:42,130
GS3 is installed, stay tuned.

198
00:09:42,130 --> 00:09:43,260
Cuz we got more videos coming up.

199
00:09:43,260 --> 00:09:44,890
We're going to show how
to get it configured and

200
00:09:44,890 --> 00:09:46,510
actually get some routers up and running.

201
00:09:46,510 --> 00:09:51,636
So stay tuned for that,
I'll see you in the next video.

202
00:09:51,636 --> 00:09:54,609
[SOUND]

episodes.title: GNS3 Initial Setup
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,362
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,362 --> 00:00:11,380
So now you've got GNS3 installed and
you're ready to use it.

3
00:00:11,380 --> 00:00:14,600
Before we can dive in and start firing up
our routers though, there are some initial

4
00:00:14,600 --> 00:00:17,692
configuration tasks we need to complete
and then we'll be ready to move forward.

5
00:00:17,692 --> 00:00:18,620
All right.

6
00:00:18,620 --> 00:00:22,240
The first time you launch GNS3, you're
going to get a little setup wizard that's

7
00:00:22,240 --> 00:00:25,940
going to pop up with the three main tasks
we need to complete to get running.

8
00:00:25,940 --> 00:00:28,780
And they're just kind of laid out here,
big, bold text.

9
00:00:28,780 --> 00:00:35,250
So, number one, configure the path to your
OS images, iOS, Qemu, PIX, etc, directory.

10
00:00:35,250 --> 00:00:37,910
This is where you should
store all of your images.

11
00:00:37,910 --> 00:00:41,150
So, it's just asking,
where you're gonna be storing your images?

12
00:00:41,150 --> 00:00:43,010
And this is stuff you can change later,

13
00:00:43,010 --> 00:00:45,890
it's not essential,
it has a default folder.

14
00:00:45,890 --> 00:00:49,920
But if you click on one, what it's doing
is it's taking you into the preferences of

15
00:00:49,920 --> 00:00:53,210
GNS3 right to the page where
you need to find that.

16
00:00:53,210 --> 00:00:56,530
So if I click on it, it's really
just going into the Preferences

17
00:00:56,530 --> 00:01:01,070
on the General tab, and
you'll see your OS images directory.

18
00:01:01,070 --> 00:01:03,450
So here's where you're gonna
be storing your images.

19
00:01:03,450 --> 00:01:08,350
And notice it picked the folder not in
C:/programfiles and it's doing that for

20
00:01:08,350 --> 00:01:10,260
permissions reasons under Windows.

21
00:01:10,260 --> 00:01:14,000
In Unix, it'll point towards your
home directory, or Linux, or OSX,

22
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:16,950
it'll point to your home
directory as well, alright.

23
00:01:16,950 --> 00:01:19,930
So that default location there,
that might be perfectly fine.

24
00:01:19,930 --> 00:01:20,950
I'm okay with it.

25
00:01:20,950 --> 00:01:23,510
So, for me,
it's c:/users/DonPezet/gns3/images.

26
00:01:23,510 --> 00:01:26,100
So, that's where I'm
gonna put my iOS files.

27
00:01:26,100 --> 00:01:30,060
You can actually put them where
ever the heck you want, but

28
00:01:30,060 --> 00:01:31,930
it's nice to have one location.

29
00:01:31,930 --> 00:01:32,490
All right.

30
00:01:32,490 --> 00:01:34,920
So as long as you're cool with that,
you go ahead and leave that be and

31
00:01:34,920 --> 00:01:36,170
hit the Okay button.

32
00:01:36,170 --> 00:01:39,310
The Okay button, which for
me is actually under my task bar, so

33
00:01:39,310 --> 00:01:45,810
let me change my task bar to auto hide
here so I can get at my Okay button.

34
00:01:45,810 --> 00:01:47,160
There we go.
All right.

35
00:01:47,160 --> 00:01:51,710
Number two, check the path to Dynamis
in the working directory are valid.

36
00:01:51,710 --> 00:01:52,680
All right.

37
00:01:52,680 --> 00:01:55,940
When it installed,
it installed a copy of Dynamips.

38
00:01:55,940 --> 00:01:58,860
But due to permissions on your hard drive,
it might not be able to

39
00:01:58,860 --> 00:02:01,590
get at those files, so
it just wants us to do a little test.

40
00:02:01,590 --> 00:02:05,675
If you've got number two, it's gonna take
you right back into the Preferences, but

41
00:02:05,675 --> 00:02:08,475
instead of the general tab
where we were a moment ago,

42
00:02:08,475 --> 00:02:12,235
it now takes us to the Dynamips tab,
alright.

43
00:02:12,235 --> 00:02:15,835
And all you need to do is a look at
that path and make sure it's valid, and

44
00:02:15,835 --> 00:02:16,525
even then, half the time,

45
00:02:16,525 --> 00:02:20,995
I don't look at that because you can just
go right down here and hit Test Settings.

46
00:02:20,995 --> 00:02:21,625
