I may need.

273
00:13:24,150 --> 00:13:27,720
So maybe I want to go in and
add that 37.25 that I mentioned.

274
00:13:27,720 --> 00:13:31,230
Notice that it defaults to 28 megs of RAM.

275
00:13:31,230 --> 00:13:35,450
So if I stick to 37 hundreds, I can
have twice as many of them on my system.

276
00:13:35,450 --> 00:13:38,630
So I'll save that one and so on.

277
00:13:38,630 --> 00:13:41,370
Once those are in there,
you can hit Close.

278
00:13:41,370 --> 00:13:46,900
And now when I go to my routers,
see how the 3700 and 7200 are lit up?

279
00:13:46,900 --> 00:13:51,600
Now, I can start to drag those out and
use them in my system.

280
00:13:51,600 --> 00:13:54,980
I'm actually ready to get in here and
start using GNS3.

281
00:13:54,980 --> 00:13:58,520
At this point,
we've completed our initial setup.

282
00:13:58,520 --> 00:13:59,980
Now, we're ready to use it.

283
00:13:59,980 --> 00:14:01,300
All right.
Well, let's stop here.

284
00:14:01,300 --> 00:14:05,290
And in our next video, we'll jump into
how to get the routers configured and

285
00:14:05,290 --> 00:14:06,310
operational.

286
00:14:06,310 --> 00:14:09,410
Actually, see some fun stuff
happening inside of GNS3.

287
00:14:09,410 --> 00:14:13,880
So, I hope to see you then.

288
00:14:13,880 --> 00:14:16,845
Take it easy.

289
00:14:16,845 --> 00:14:17,624
[NOISE]

episodes.title: Launching Your First Router
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:03,886
[SOUND] All right, so

2
00:00:03,886 --> 00:00:10,252
now we've got GNS3 installed.

3
00:00:10,252 --> 00:00:12,870
It's set up, and it's ready to rock!

4
00:00:12,870 --> 00:00:13,940
Let's get to work!

5
00:00:13,940 --> 00:00:16,720
Well, there's actually just
a little bit more to it.

6
00:00:16,720 --> 00:00:17,610
We can drag and

7
00:00:17,610 --> 00:00:20,890
drop our routers right onto the screen and
start to build our environment.

8
00:00:20,890 --> 00:00:25,750
But getting that first router set up can
actually be a little bit daunting because

9
00:00:25,750 --> 00:00:27,770
of the idle PC value.

10
00:00:27,770 --> 00:00:30,950
Idle PC is something that we need
to get configured on the system

11
00:00:30,950 --> 00:00:34,060
in order to get the system
to run efficiently.

12
00:00:34,060 --> 00:00:35,050
Now wat do I mean by that?

13
00:00:35,050 --> 00:00:42,170
Well when the Cisco IOS fires up, it is
the only thing running on a Cisco router.

14
00:00:42,170 --> 00:00:46,080
That whole set of hardware is
dedicated entirely to the IOS.

15
00:00:46,080 --> 00:00:51,300
So when the IOS fires up, it immediately
reserves 100% of the memory and

16
00:00:51,300 --> 00:00:54,050
100% of the CPU on the system.

17
00:00:54,050 --> 00:00:56,660
Well, as far as memory,
I've got these things capped.

18
00:00:56,660 --> 00:00:59,180
Right?
So if I take one of these 7200's,

19
00:00:59,180 --> 00:01:01,370
it's capped at 256 megs of RAM.

20
00:01:01,370 --> 00:01:06,680
So when I drag it out, if it consumes 256
megs of RAM, I'm okay with that, right?

21
00:01:06,680 --> 00:01:10,380
I think I have 8 gigs of RAM on my laptop,
or 16, or something like that.

22
00:01:10,380 --> 00:01:13,080
So, I've got plenty of memory
to be able to handle that.

23
00:01:13,080 --> 00:01:17,460
But CPU, if it tries to grab a 100% of my
CPU, what's that gonna do to the system?

24
00:01:17,460 --> 00:01:20,340
It's going to slow it to a crawl.

25
00:01:20,340 --> 00:01:24,610
So what Idle PC does, is it looks at that
and it says all right, the router is only

26
00:01:24,610 --> 00:01:30,790
doing so much, the rest of the CPU that
it's consuming are just idle timers.

27
00:01:30,790 --> 00:01:36,630
And we can exclude those idle timers
to free up that CPU back to our system.

28
00:01:36,630 --> 00:01:41,450
So if I just throw a router out there
on my system and start it up, I'll

29
00:01:41,450 --> 00:01:46,350
see that my system runs kind of poorly
until I calculate out an idle PC value.

30
00:01:46,350 --> 00:01:49,850
Now, You'll hear a lot of people say
different things about how to do this.

31
00:01:49,850 --> 00:01:51,540
I'm gonna show you what works best for me.

32
00:01:52,570 --> 00:01:54,930
When you first take a router out,
so I'll take this 7200.

33
00:01:54,930 --> 00:01:57,290
I'm gonna drag it out here and
throw it out.

34
00:01:57,290 --> 00:01:59,650
So now I've got router two.

35
00:01:59,650 --> 00:02:02,290
Now, it's turned off.

36
00:02:02,290 --> 00:02:04,850
I can tell that cuz right here where it
says router two it's got a nice little red

37
00:02:04,850 --> 00:02:10,050
circle by it so I know it's not running,
and if I look at my task manager, I

38
00:02:10,050 --> 00:02:14,540
can look at my performance and I can kind
of see how my system's running right now.

39
00:02:14,540 --> 00:02:17,720
I'm averaging, you know it looks
like about 20% CPU right now.

40
00:02:17,720 --> 00:02:20,980
That's gonna be my
screen sharing software.

41
00:02:20,980 --> 00:02:25,260
My screen sharing software consumes a good
bit of CPU and so I'm losing about 20%.

42
00:02:25,260 --> 00:02:26,700
But the system's kind of flatlined.

43
00:02:26,700 --> 00:02:29,610
You'll see it's just operating
right there at about 20%.

44
00:02:29,610 --> 00:02:30,660
All right?

45
00:02:30,660 --> 00:02:32,410
Watch when I start this router.

46
00:02:32,410 --> 00:02:35,585
Let me make this always on top, there.

47
00:02:35,585 --> 00:02:41,610
There, okay, so let me give this a second
so we can see that flatline again.

48
00:02:41,610 --> 00:02:43,630
And I'm gonna start that router and
we're gonna see that change.

49
00:02:43,630 --> 00:02:45,640
So I see it flatlining at 20% again.

50
00:02:46,890 --> 00:02:48,460
And now I'm gonna start this router,

51
00:02:48,460 --> 00:02:52,940
to start it I just right click on it, if
you right click on it you can go to start.

52
00:02:52,940 --> 00:02:56,360
This little green arrow right here,
I'll go ahead and start it up, all right.

53
00:02:56,360 --> 00:02:58,690
Now when it start's it
takes it a moment right?

54
00:02:58,690 --> 00:03:00,960
It's booting up just like
a real Cisco router, and

55
00:03:00,960 --> 00:03:03,320
watch my CPU utilization
when that happens.

56
00:03:03,320 --> 00:03:03,880
All right.

57
00:03:03,880 --> 00:03:05,800
So it's starting to creep up and

58
00:03:05,800 --> 00:03:10,260
that's because that router is consuming
more CPU than it should right.

59
00:03:10,260 --> 00:03:16,100
So now I've gone from averaging 20%
CPU to averaging close to 50% CPU.

60
00:03:16,100 --> 00:03:18,912
Now I've got multiple
cores in this system.

61
00:03:18,912 --> 00:03:21,670
Cisco routers don't
recognize multiple cores so

62
00:03:21,670 --> 00:03:25,190
it can't exceed the core and
in this view I don't really see it.

63
00:03:25,190 --> 00:03:28,410
See how I've got two cores and
four logical processors.

64
00:03:28,410 --> 00:03:32,850
So I'm averaging 50% since these
routers are single threaded

65
00:03:32,850 --> 00:03:35,640
that means I'm maxing out one
of the cores in my laptop.

66
00:03:35,640 --> 00:03:38,000
One of my cores is running at 100%.

67
00:03:38,000 --> 00:03:43,680
So I need to fix that, most of this is
just junk process anyway, it's just idles

68
00:03:43,680 --> 00:03:47,290
that are being held cuz the iOS is use
to having full reign on the CPU, right.

69
00:03:48,460 --> 00:03:50,830
So what we do is while
the router is running,

70
00:03:50,830 --> 00:03:53,250
we need to run a little scan on
it to figure out what's idle.

71
00:03:53,250 --> 00:03:57,530
Now, it's been my experience that if
you just try and do this right off,

72
00:03:57,530 --> 00:03:59,040
it never quite works right.

73
00:03:59,040 --> 00:04:03,130
The best thing to do is to open
up a console connection first.

74
00:04:03,130 --> 00:04:05,900
On a brand new router one of the things
you wanna do is plug into the console

75
00:04:05,900 --> 00:04:07,510
port so you can start to work with it.

76
00:04:07,510 --> 00:04:11,980
Well since these are virtual routers, we
virtually connect to their console port.

77
00:04:11,980 --> 00:04:13,860
If you right click on the router,

78
00:04:13,860 --> 00:04:17,020
you'll see an option here
that says console, alright.

79
00:04:17,020 --> 00:04:20,790
And we can choose that, not this console
via AUX, right, that's the auxiliary port.

80
00:04:20,790 --> 00:04:22,510
We want this one that just says Console.

81
00:04:22,510 --> 00:04:27,460
And when you click on that,
it'll use putty and fire up and

82
00:04:27,460 --> 00:04:30,060
get you a console interface, all right?

83
00:04:30,060 --> 00:04:34,450
I find that the idle PC
values never work right

84
00:04:34,450 --> 00:04:37,870
unless you're actually at
just a regular router prompt.

85
00:04:37,870 --> 00:04:40,510
If it's still sitting there saying
press return to get started,

86
00:04:40,510 --> 00:04:43,310
a lot of times the idle
PC values don't work.

87
00:04:43,310 --> 00:04:45,080
So I'm just making here
that I'm right here.

88
00:04:45,080 --> 00:04:49,730
The router is finished booting up, and
the router is actually sitting there idle.

89
00:04:49,730 --> 00:04:51,770
That's what you really want,
the router doing nothing.

90
00:04:52,780 --> 00:04:57,430
Now that I know that it's there,
I can go back, and

91
00:04:57,430 --> 00:05:00,080
let me just kind of move this
out of the way a little bit,

92
00:05:00,080 --> 00:05:04,985
I can go back in here and
I can right click on the router.

93
00:05:04,985 --> 00:05:09,280
[LAUGH] Trying to find a place where we
can stick this where we can still see it,

94
00:05:09,280 --> 00:05:11,420
but it's not a super burden for us.

95
00:05:11,420 --> 00:05:15,350
We can right click on the router and
you will see an option called idle PC.

96
00:05:15,350 --> 00:05:18,160
That's where we go to calculate
that idle PC value and

97
00:05:18,160 --> 00:05:21,220
when you click on it's
going to run a scan.

98
00:05:21,220 --> 00:05:23,595
Now if you have already done this,

99
00:05:23,595 --> 00:05:28,170
it'll disable the idle PC value you've
already got, so you'll see your CPU go up.

100
00:05:28,170 --> 00:05:30,920
My CPU is already up
because I've never run it.

101
00:05:30,920 --> 00:05:35,920
It runs a scan and it tries to identify
the idle processes on the router.

102
00:05:35,920 --> 00:05:38,530
And so you'll get a little
pop-up that looks like this and

103
00:05:38,530 --> 00:05:43,380
it has a drop-down box with a number
of hexadecimal addresses in it.

104
00:05:43,380 --> 00:05:44,030
All right.

105
00:05:44,030 --> 00:05:48,440
It's trying to identify which
hex address contains the idle

106
00:05:48,440 --> 00:05:49,830
sequences for the router.

107
00:05:51,050 --> 00:05:56,180
If we pick the right one,
we'll see our CP utilization drop.

108
00:05:56,180 --> 00:05:59,160
If we pick the wrong one,
our CP utilization will stay high.

109
00:05:59,160 --> 00:06:00,560
All right?

110
00:06:00,560 --> 00:06:02,370
Well, it tries to help you out.

111
00:06:02,370 --> 00:06:05,540
It looks and
it figures out the most likely candidates.

112
00:06:05,540 --> 00:06:08,220
The most likely candidates will
have an asterisk beside them.

113
00:06:08,220 --> 00:06:12,500
So see I've got two right here with
asterisks on the left side, right.

114
00:06:12,500 --> 00:06:14,140
So it's gonna be one of these two.

115
00:06:14,140 --> 00:06:17,930
I've got one that's you know a hex
address and so is the other one.

116
00:06:17,930 --> 00:06:22,800
And then in square brackets beside it
one says 52 and one says 57, all right.

117
00:06:22,800 --> 00:06:25,990
If you have more than one
value with an asterisk.

118
00:06:25,990 --> 00:06:29,410
You generally wanna pick the one with
the highest number in brackets, so

119
00:06:29,410 --> 00:06:31,140
I've got 52 and 57.

120
00:06:31,140 --> 00:06:33,480
I'll pick 57, all right?

121
00:06:33,480 --> 00:06:36,670
If you've got a tie, if you've got
more than one with an asterisk,

122
00:06:36,670 --> 00:06:39,020
pick the one with the highest
number in brackets.

123
00:06:39,020 --> 00:06:42,840
If you've only got one with an asterisk,
then you know which one to pick.

124
00:06:42,840 --> 00:06:46,120
If you've got none with an asterisk,
it usually means it

125
00:06:46,120 --> 00:06:50,220
couldn't identify the idle sequences, this
typically happens if the router is busy

126
00:06:50,220 --> 00:06:54,330
doing something when you run the idle PC
calculation and you need to run it again.

127
00:06:54,330 --> 00:06:57,680
All right, but if you run it a few
times and you still don't get one with

128
00:06:57,680 --> 00:07:01,310
an asterisk, you can just try and pick
which ever one has the highest number.

129
00:07:01,310 --> 00:07:04,725
You'll know right away whether it works if
you're watching your system utilization

130
00:07:04,725 --> 00:07:06,140
cuz you'll actually see it.

131
00:07:06,140 --> 00:07:11,520
So for me, if I take this I can
see what I'm running at right now.

132
00:07:12,530 --> 00:07:14,980
Alright, so there I am kind of
running it at that 50% CPU,

133
00:07:14,980 --> 00:07:17,680
let me make that a little bit bigger.

134
00:07:17,680 --> 00:07:18,300
There, so

135
00:07:18,300 --> 00:07:23,280
I can see myself running it at a 50% CPU,
I'm gonna pick this value and hit apply.

136
00:07:23,280 --> 00:07:23,940
Okay.

137
00:07:23,940 --> 00:07:27,030
When you hit apply it takes effect,
and if you picked the right one,

138
00:07:27,030 --> 00:07:29,520
you 'll see exactly what I just saw.

139
00:07:29,520 --> 00:07:30,360
All right.

140
00:07:30,360 --> 00:07:34,770
My system was running at 20% CPU
before because of my screen share,

141
00:07:34,770 --> 00:07:38,360
it jumped up to 50% CPU
when I started the router.

142
00:07:38,360 --> 00:07:44,090
Now that I applied that idle PC,
it dropped down and I'm averaging 22%.

143
00:07:44,090 --> 00:07:47,342
So that means that the router
is really only consuming 1% or

144
00:07:47,342 --> 00:07:51,320
2% of my system, versus the 30%
it was consuming a moment ago.

145
00:07:51,320 --> 00:07:54,531
That makes a big difference,
if you're gonna run more than on router,

146
00:07:54,531 --> 00:07:56,671
you've got to calculate
out an idle PCU value,

147
00:07:56,671 --> 00:07:59,042
otherwise you're just gonna
run out of resources.

148
00:07:59,042 --> 00:08:02,672
It doesn't matter how beefy your system
is, and if this is the wrong one, if it

149
00:08:02,672 --> 00:08:06,583
didn't work, you can just drop it down and
pick some of the other values, you know.

150
00:08:06,583 --> 00:08:09,208
Experiment around until you find
the one that gets you the best result.

151
00:08:09,208 --> 00:08:12,292
So if I switch here to
this one that says 31.

152
00:08:12,292 --> 00:08:15,140
Well, actually, it looks like you
get about the same on that one.

153
00:08:15,140 --> 00:08:17,090
Not seeing much difference there.

154
00:08:17,090 --> 00:08:19,170
So, you can kind of roam around these.

155
00:08:19,170 --> 00:08:21,830
Hitting apply each time
to see which one works.

156
00:08:21,830 --> 00:08:25,030
For me, that, yeah,
it all seems to be about the same.

157
00:08:25,030 --> 00:08:27,030
So I'll stick with the 57.

158
00:08:27,030 --> 00:08:27,530
And hit OK.

159
00:08:29,130 --> 00:08:33,100
Now, I've got an idle PC value
calculated for router 2.

160
00:08:33,100 --> 00:08:39,480
And that means that for
any 7200 series router that I bring out.

161
00:08:39,480 --> 00:08:40,950
It's going have that idle PC value.

162
00:08:40,950 --> 00:08:45,040
So if I grab another 7200 and
throw it out here, and I start it up.

163
00:08:46,130 --> 00:08:48,420
There it goes, and watch my CPUs.

164
00:08:48,420 --> 00:08:51,120
My CPU just went to 50%.

165
00:08:51,120 --> 00:08:55,130
Well, the router's starting, it's actually
doing a lot right now while it boots up.

166
00:08:55,130 --> 00:09:00,420
And I can watch it in the console, and
see it go through its boot process.

167
00:09:00,420 --> 00:09:01,540
So here it goes booting up.

168
00:09:02,960 --> 00:09:04,960
And then when it's done.

169
00:09:04,960 --> 00:09:07,020
See that my CPU spiked back down.

170
00:09:07,020 --> 00:09:11,120
It finished booting, I got to a regular
prompt, and now it drops back down, and

171
00:09:11,120 --> 00:09:12,630
there we are.

172
00:09:12,630 --> 00:09:14,310
So keep an eye on that.

173
00:09:15,320 --> 00:09:18,480
You may need to recalculate
idle PC values later on.

174
00:09:18,480 --> 00:09:20,750
For example, say you start to
turn on a bunch of features.

175
00:09:20,750 --> 00:09:23,160
You turn on VPN and all that stuff.

176
00:09:23,160 --> 00:09:26,440
Well, your idle PC value might
not truly be accurate anymore.

177
00:09:26,440 --> 00:09:30,680
If you start to see your CPU utilizations
climbing, just recalculate the Idle CPU.

178
00:09:31,690 --> 00:09:33,690
Just keep in mind it is
done on the platform.

179
00:09:33,690 --> 00:09:35,370
So when I calculate it here for
this router,

180
00:09:35,370 --> 00:09:39,060
it's going to apply for
every 7200 that I start up out there.

181
00:09:39,060 --> 00:09:41,730
If I start up a different platform.

182
00:09:41,730 --> 00:09:45,380
So, let's say, I take a 3600 and
I'll throw it out here.

183
00:09:45,380 --> 00:09:45,990
Alright.

184
00:09:45,990 --> 00:09:47,960
So, here's router 4, it's a 3600.

185
00:09:47,960 --> 00:09:51,870
When I start it up, well,
it's going to fire up.

186
00:09:51,870 --> 00:09:54,380
And it's a different hardware platform.

187
00:09:54,380 --> 00:09:57,360
So, the idle PC is not
going to apply to it.

188
00:09:57,360 --> 00:09:59,670
So here it's booting.

189
00:10:01,160 --> 00:10:03,890
I'm sitting here at a nice
flat command prompt, and

190
00:10:03,890 --> 00:10:06,230
my CPU utilization is still high.

191
00:10:06,230 --> 00:10:10,140
So I'll need to calculate an idle CPU for
that one too.

192
00:10:10,140 --> 00:10:12,840
Same process just right click on it and
go to idle PC.

193
00:10:14,750 --> 00:10:18,440
And it's recalculating there in
the background, just shows the GNS3 logo.

194
00:10:18,440 --> 00:10:21,810
And it says right here,
please wait while calculating idle PC.

195
00:10:21,810 --> 00:10:24,840
You typically don't want to be doing other
things on your system while that runs.

196
00:10:26,010 --> 00:10:30,180
And it looks like I've only got one value
with an asterisk this time, just that one.

197
00:10:31,890 --> 00:10:33,680
Let's see how well it works.

198
00:10:33,680 --> 00:10:35,530
So we'll go ahead and apply that.

199
00:10:35,530 --> 00:10:38,170
And sure enough that was the right one.

200
00:10:38,170 --> 00:10:43,300
Real important, you don't have to have
a beefy machine to run these routers.

201
00:10:43,300 --> 00:10:46,630
Most Cisco routers have very
antiquated CPU's in them.

202
00:10:46,630 --> 00:10:49,640
And that's because they have ASIC's in
them, application specific integrated

203
00:10:49,640 --> 00:10:52,770
circuits that are doing the true routing,
and decision making.

204
00:10:52,770 --> 00:10:56,110
The CPU is really just booting the IOS and
throwing it in RAM.

205
00:10:56,110 --> 00:10:58,030
So they'll have 486s.

206
00:10:58,030 --> 00:10:59,610
They'll have Cyrix processors.

207
00:10:59,610 --> 00:11:01,320
They'll have all sorts of
weird processors in there.

208
00:11:01,320 --> 00:11:04,190
PPCs, the old power PC processors.

209
00:11:04,190 --> 00:11:07,070
They'll have stuff like that,
because that's all they need.

210
00:11:07,070 --> 00:11:09,490
It doesn't take a beefy machine to do it.

211
00:11:09,490 --> 00:11:12,010
But if you don't calculate an idle PC,

212
00:11:12,010 --> 00:11:14,240
those routers can bring
your system to a crawl.

213
00:11:14,240 --> 00:11:19,240
Even though your CPU was way better
than what might be in a physical router.

214
00:11:19,240 --> 00:11:25,050
Once that's done, now we're ready to
get in there and start using GNS3.

215
00:11:25,050 --> 00:11:27,230
So, we've got tat value configured.

216
00:11:28,400 --> 00:11:30,240
Now it's time to set up our routers.

217
00:11:30,240 --> 00:11:32,650
Now I've already dragged
out a few routers here.

218
00:11:32,650 --> 00:11:35,560
And kind of shown you what's involved
with just throwing them out there on

219
00:11:35,560 --> 00:11:36,060
the screen.

220
00:11:37,110 --> 00:11:38,990
We might be ready to go and fire them up.

221
00:11:38,990 --> 00:11:40,890
But typically we need to do a little more.

222
00:11:40,890 --> 00:11:43,330
We need to tweak their
hardware to meet our needs.

223
00:11:43,330 --> 00:11:44,130
And we need to plug them in.

224
00:11:44,130 --> 00:11:45,930
There's no cables between these routers.

225
00:11:45,930 --> 00:11:49,170
So they're not gonna be very
effective without a cable.

226
00:11:49,170 --> 00:11:52,640
Well, the first thing we need to know is
how to turn on and off these routers.

227
00:11:52,640 --> 00:11:54,870
When you right click on them
you get this full menu.

228
00:11:54,870 --> 00:11:59,470
And you'll see Start, Suspend, and Stop.

229
00:11:59,470 --> 00:12:02,040
Start powers them on,
Stop powers them off.

230
00:12:02,040 --> 00:12:04,390
Suspend freezes them in time.

231
00:12:04,390 --> 00:12:07,440
It's like taking a snapshot
of a virtual machine.

232
00:12:07,440 --> 00:12:11,190
It freezes it in time, stops it running so
you can resume it later on.

233
00:12:11,190 --> 00:12:16,440
Alright, now once you start them, they're
fired up and they're ready to work with.

234
00:12:16,440 --> 00:12:19,600
If they're started up you'll see a little
green light on the router name on

235
00:12:19,600 --> 00:12:21,930
the right side here in our summary.

236
00:12:21,930 --> 00:12:24,240
So you can see whether they're on or off.

237
00:12:24,240 --> 00:12:27,020
Alright, you'll also get
a list of their interfaces if

238
00:12:27,020 --> 00:12:28,000
you have anything plugged in.

239
00:12:28,000 --> 00:12:29,340
Mine aren't plugged in.

240
00:12:29,340 --> 00:12:31,800
Alright, one quick word of advice.

241
00:12:31,800 --> 00:12:37,630
I've got that stop button, and
start and suspend and a reload button.

242
00:12:37,630 --> 00:12:42,190
If you ever wanna reboot your router, you
wanna right-click on it and choose reload.

243
00:12:42,190 --> 00:12:46,150
Now you might say, well can't I just
reload it from the inside of the router?

244
00:12:46,150 --> 00:12:51,070
Well because the storage of
the router is being emulated,

245
00:12:51,070 --> 00:12:53,550
it can't actually do its own reload.

246
00:12:53,550 --> 00:12:55,430
So like, here I am on this router three.

247
00:12:55,430 --> 00:12:59,550
If I run DIR, that would
normally show me what's in flash.

248
00:12:59,550 --> 00:13:03,780
But these routers don't have true flash,
because the storage system is emulated.

249
00:13:03,780 --> 00:13:05,460
So they don't see the IOS.

250
00:13:05,460 --> 00:13:09,790
So if I do a reload from here It's
not gonna be very happy about that.

251
00:13:09,790 --> 00:13:11,710
And in fact the router's gonna
lock back up, I believe.

252
00:13:11,710 --> 00:13:12,920
Let's give it a second here.

253
00:13:12,920 --> 00:13:15,340
Here's a ROM reload, and then it freezes.

254
00:13:15,340 --> 00:13:17,310
So here it is just kinda stuck.

255
00:13:17,310 --> 00:13:18,780
And it's not actually reloading.

256
00:13:18,780 --> 00:13:19,660
All right?

257
00:13:19,660 --> 00:13:23,830
So if you wanna reload your router,
don't do it from inside of the router.

258
00:13:23,830 --> 00:13:26,000
Instead do it from here.

259
00:13:26,000 --> 00:13:29,390
Just right-click on the router and
choose reload, and it'll do it.

260
00:13:29,390 --> 00:13:33,360
That'll handle the issues with having
virtualized storage, all right?

261
00:13:33,360 --> 00:13:36,160
Every other command on the router works,
except for

262
00:13:36,160 --> 00:13:38,210
the commands that interact with storage.

263
00:13:38,210 --> 00:13:43,590
So, when it comes to upgrading an iOS
image, or reloading the router like that.

264
00:13:43,590 --> 00:13:45,630
The virtualized storage causes a problem.

265
00:13:45,630 --> 00:13:46,680
Saving your configs.

266
00:13:46,680 --> 00:13:47,790
That's fine.

267
00:13:47,790 --> 00:13:50,810
Even putting like the IPS
signature files on there.

268
00:13:50,810 --> 00:13:52,500
That's fine.
That stuff all works.

269
00:13:52,500 --> 00:13:55,360
But this one little piece doesn't.

270
00:13:55,360 --> 00:13:57,720
So, just want to point that
out here before we get to far.

271
00:13:59,140 --> 00:14:01,110
Alright, other things we
might want to customize.

272
00:14:01,110 --> 00:14:03,680
If you take your router, and shut it down.

273
00:14:03,680 --> 00:14:06,140
So I'm just going to hit
stop to power off router 2.

274
00:14:06,140 --> 00:14:08,090
So router 2 is now powered off.

275
00:14:08,090 --> 00:14:12,630
While they're off you can right
click on them and choose configure.

276
00:14:12,630 --> 00:14:17,950
When you go to configure them, here's
where we can go and choose our hardware.

277
00:14:17,950 --> 00:14:21,290
I've got a 7200 VXR,
that's what this router is.

278
00:14:21,290 --> 00:14:24,830
And so when I click on router 2 here,
I'll see that hardware laid out.

279
00:14:24,830 --> 00:14:28,090
And I can start to pick
some different adjustments,

280
00:14:28,090 --> 00:14:30,320
do I want this to be a standard 7200?

281
00:14:30,320 --> 00:14:34,390
The older one, or do I want it to
be a VXR which is the newer one?

282
00:14:34,390 --> 00:14:40,290
I can pick from the NPE, our processing
engine that's inside of there.

283
00:14:40,290 --> 00:14:43,500
When you buy a 7200,
the processing engine that sticks in it.

284
00:14:43,500 --> 00:14:45,580
It has a couple of network
jacks that are on it.

285
00:14:45,580 --> 00:14:48,960
And which engine you pick,
supports different things.

286
00:14:48,960 --> 00:14:52,530
By default, it goes to the NPE 400,
which is one of the more powerful ones.

287
00:14:52,530 --> 00:14:53,800
And, so,
that's what we normally stick with.

288
00:14:54,830 --> 00:14:56,730
You've got memory and disk.

289
00:14:56,730 --> 00:15:00,370
Here's where I can pick how much
RAM it has and how much NV RAM.

290
00:15:00,370 --> 00:15:03,230
The defaults are normally more
than suitable for us, but

291
00:15:03,230 --> 00:15:04,490
in your environment you might need more.

292
00:15:04,490 --> 00:15:05,820
You might need a little
more storage in there.

293
00:15:05,820 --> 00:15:09,020
You can bump it up, or
add more RAM to it if you want, alright.

294
00:15:09,020 --> 00:15:12,360
This particular router has
removable flash in it.

295
00:15:12,360 --> 00:15:15,060
So it's got here where I can pick
how much removable flash it's got.

296
00:15:16,870 --> 00:15:19,300
Keep in mind that this is going
to be limited by the iOS.

297
00:15:19,300 --> 00:15:21,940
The iOS can only address flash
cards of a certain size.

298
00:15:21,940 --> 00:15:24,220
Just depends on which version
of iOS you're running.

299
00:15:24,220 --> 00:15:29,570
You could specify a value here that's too
big, typically we stick with the defaults.

300
00:15:29,570 --> 00:15:32,010
Slots though, this is the fun part.

301
00:15:32,010 --> 00:15:34,290
Most of your Cisco routers are modular.

302
00:15:34,290 --> 00:15:38,100
They've got slots in them where you can
add in different cards and functionality.

303
00:15:38,100 --> 00:15:39,920
And, here's where we can pick that.

304
00:15:39,920 --> 00:15:41,190
A 7200 is a big router.

305
00:15:41,190 --> 00:15:43,750
It's got a ton of slots.

306
00:15:43,750 --> 00:15:48,210
Other routers, like a 2600,
is a small router.

307
00:15:48,210 --> 00:15:50,210
It doesn't have a lot of slots.

308
00:15:50,210 --> 00:15:54,250
So, if I go to configure it,
And I go to it's slots page.

309
00:15:54,250 --> 00:15:56,292
You'll see most of these
slots are grayed out.

310
00:15:56,292 --> 00:15:58,060
I can't click on them, all right.

311
00:15:58,060 --> 00:16:02,600
In fact it's got two slots, and
two wicks that I pick from.

312
00:16:02,600 --> 00:16:07,470
And so here it's got two Fast Ethernet
ports inserted in the router right now.

313
00:16:07,470 --> 00:16:09,880
I could add some more,
another Fast Ethernet or

314
00:16:09,880 --> 00:16:12,890
one of those 16-port switch
cards that are terrible.

315
00:16:12,890 --> 00:16:16,610
Whatever it is that I wanna put in
the system, I can choose that card.

316
00:16:16,610 --> 00:16:20,404
Down here I can pick the WICs,
do I want it to have a WIC-1T, a WIC-2T?

317
00:16:20,404 --> 00:16:25,660
And I can even double that up so if I want
this to be like some kind of centralized

318
00:16:25,660 --> 00:16:30,280
T1 concentrator I could have four serial
ports right there to be able to use.

319
00:16:30,280 --> 00:16:34,070
And you'll see other options up here for
adding in those different connections.

320
00:16:34,070 --> 00:16:38,060
A lot of different choices and
it does vary based on the router.

321
00:16:38,060 --> 00:16:39,780
If I go back to my 7200,

322
00:16:39,780 --> 00:16:43,760
it's got a lot more options,
because it's a bigger router.

323
00:16:43,760 --> 00:16:47,725
So when you go in here I can add a Fast
Ethernet or two Fast Ethernet jacks,

324
00:16:47,725 --> 00:16:49,670
a gigabit Ethernet jack.

325
00:16:49,670 --> 00:16:53,609
And you'll see different ports,
here's the four serial ports,

326
00:16:53,609 --> 00:16:57,990
eight serial ports, we can go crazy,
add in a OC3 because, why not?

327
00:16:57,990 --> 00:16:58,630
Right.

328
00:16:58,630 --> 00:17:01,730
A lot of this is equipment that
we might not be able to afford or

329
00:17:01,730 --> 00:17:03,760
might not have access to in real life.

330
00:17:03,760 --> 00:17:06,338
But here is virtual,
build out what you want right?

331
00:17:06,338 --> 00:17:08,034
You want to set up your own ISDN switch?

332
00:17:08,034 --> 00:17:11,858
Great, add in some of these 8T cards and
you'll be able to have

333
00:17:11,858 --> 00:17:16,710
many many serial ports, set up your own
ISDN switch and get to running, right?

334
00:17:16,710 --> 00:17:19,970
Maybe you don't want to set up your
own ISDN switch but you want to just

335
00:17:19,970 --> 00:17:23,020
automatically have one in place, well
we'll see a little bit later where there's

336
00:17:23,020 --> 00:17:26,920
some ISDN switches and stuff like that,
that are already defined that we can use.

337
00:17:26,920 --> 00:17:30,550
But you've got control you pick what
you want that system to have and

338
00:17:30,550 --> 00:17:34,012
you get it configured how you need it.

339
00:17:34,012 --> 00:17:37,510
All right, so for
my 7200 maybe I want a handful of

340
00:17:38,710 --> 00:17:43,150
Fast Ethernet jacks so I'll just
add in a couple of these 2FE cards.

341
00:17:43,150 --> 00:17:43,920
There we go.

342
00:17:43,920 --> 00:17:45,530
So now I've got six of these.

343
00:17:45,530 --> 00:17:48,980
Notice this first one, this is what's
built into the router itself, and

344
00:17:48,980 --> 00:17:54,409
then I've added two more cards to get
six of these Fast Ethernet jacks.

345
00:17:54,409 --> 00:17:57,750
All right, now the cards themselves don't

346
00:17:57,750 --> 00:18:01,020
do us a heck of a lot of good until
we start to plug our cables in, so

347
00:18:01,020 --> 00:18:05,280
that's kind of the next part is we need
to start cabling these systems together.

348
00:18:05,280 --> 00:18:08,640
While you might be plugging your router
directly into another router, or

349
00:18:08,640 --> 00:18:10,690
you might be plugging into switches.

350
00:18:10,690 --> 00:18:13,680
And so that's kinda the next thing,
is when you need to bring in switches and

351
00:18:13,680 --> 00:18:14,670
get them in here.

352
00:18:14,670 --> 00:18:18,100
But I think I'll hold that off for
another segment.

353
00:18:18,100 --> 00:18:20,360
As far as getting our
initial router configured,

354
00:18:20,360 --> 00:18:21,960
we've kinda seen what we need to do.

355
00:18:21,960 --> 00:18:26,130
Configure your idle PC, configure your
memory, configure your cards, right?

356
00:18:26,130 --> 00:18:27,700
Change that however you want.

357
00:18:27,700 --> 00:18:30,070
Once that's done,
the router's ready to rock.

358
00:18:30,070 --> 00:18:32,730
You can start it up, and it's ready to go.

359
00:18:32,730 --> 00:18:35,020
To start it you just right-click and
hit Start.

360
00:18:35,020 --> 00:18:38,290
And from there you can right-click and
hit Console to connect

361
00:18:38,290 --> 00:18:42,140
right to the console port of that router
and start to work with it, right?

362
00:18:42,140 --> 00:18:43,810
After you've assigned it an IP address and

363
00:18:43,810 --> 00:18:46,190
all that then you can start
remoting into it through Telnet or

364
00:18:46,190 --> 00:18:51,060
SSH but when it's initially firing up,
you'll want to use this console port.

365
00:18:52,380 --> 00:18:54,440
So here it goes, firing up.

366
00:18:54,440 --> 00:18:56,280
And we're in, right.

367
00:18:56,280 --> 00:18:59,970
So here we are,
I can do a show IP interface brief.

368
00:19:01,560 --> 00:19:04,070
And here's those network
jacks that I added in.

369
00:19:04,070 --> 00:19:06,640
I've got the FE0/0 that was onboard.

370
00:19:06,640 --> 00:19:09,030
I thought I had two onboard,
but I guess just one.

371
00:19:09,030 --> 00:19:12,580
And then here's the first card I added and
the second card that I added.

372
00:19:12,580 --> 00:19:17,170
So I've got five Fast Ethernet ports
cause of the cards that I chose, right?

373
00:19:17,170 --> 00:19:18,490
You can pick whatever you need.

374
00:19:18,490 --> 00:19:21,330
I didn't do any serial ports,
right, so I could add those in and

375
00:19:21,330 --> 00:19:22,660
really had some fun.

376
00:19:22,660 --> 00:19:25,140
Keep in mind that it is
just like a real router,

377
00:19:25,140 --> 00:19:28,090
if the router is online I
can't add hardware to it.

378
00:19:28,090 --> 00:19:31,890
So if I go into it's configuration
while the router is on and

379
00:19:31,890 --> 00:19:35,500
you start adjusting things it's not
going to be very happy about that.

380
00:19:35,500 --> 00:19:39,717
So if I start to add a bunch of
these 8T cards in and hit OK well,

381
00:19:39,717 --> 00:19:44,769
see I'm getting some unable to add
binding messages and stuff like that.

382
00:19:44,769 --> 00:19:46,834
And that's because
the router is actually on.

383
00:19:46,834 --> 00:19:51,338
So I need to power it off Just like
in real life, and then go in here and

384
00:19:51,338 --> 00:19:53,410
modify it's configuration.

385
00:19:53,410 --> 00:19:57,300
So I'll go back here into my slots,
it at least remembered it.

386
00:19:57,300 --> 00:20:01,110
We'll go ahead and say OK,
oh I may have really made it unhappy.

387
00:20:01,110 --> 00:20:03,000
Well, we'll find out here in a second.

388
00:20:03,000 --> 00:20:05,100
I'm just gonna start it up and
connect back to it's console and

389
00:20:05,100 --> 00:20:07,900
we should see whether or
not it picked up those cards.

390
00:20:07,900 --> 00:20:12,200
So try not to modify the hardware while
the router is running that's the moral

391
00:20:12,200 --> 00:20:12,730
of that story.

392
00:20:13,790 --> 00:20:14,870
All right, let's see if this shows up.

393
00:20:14,870 --> 00:20:15,520
Oh, it looks like it did.

394
00:20:15,520 --> 00:20:18,590
See how I have five
Fast Ethernet interfaces and

395
00:20:18,590 --> 00:20:20,979
16 cereal ports that it's now picked up.

396
00:20:22,740 --> 00:20:24,380
You'll see a few warnings
when you boot up,

397
00:20:24,380 --> 00:20:27,190
just like on a normal router you'll see
your interfaces come up and come down.

398
00:20:27,190 --> 00:20:30,250
But there was also a warning
up there about a crash dump.

399
00:20:30,250 --> 00:20:31,770
And, let's see, where did it go?

400
00:20:31,770 --> 00:20:34,440
Somewhere in here there was
a warning about a crash dump.

401
00:20:34,440 --> 00:20:38,050
Right there, Crashinfo may not be
recovered at bootflash:crashinfo.

402
00:20:38,050 --> 00:20:42,100
The problem is it's trying to look at the
storage to see if there's a crash file.

403
00:20:42,100 --> 00:20:44,580
But the storage is emulated so
it can't find it.

404
00:20:44,580 --> 00:20:45,570
So that's what that error is.

405
00:20:45,570 --> 00:20:47,590
That's what you'll normally see,
is issues with those.

406
00:20:49,170 --> 00:20:51,770
But if I do a show ip interface brief now,

407
00:20:51,770 --> 00:20:53,770
there's all those serial
ports that I just added.

408
00:20:53,770 --> 00:20:58,310
So I got a nice, big chunk of serial
connectivity I can start to work with.

409
00:20:58,310 --> 00:20:58,870
Really neat stuff.

410
00:20:59,880 --> 00:21:02,030
All right, so
that's our initial router configuration.

411
00:21:02,030 --> 00:21:06,010
Stay tuned, we've got more videos
coming up as we cover switches and

412
00:21:06,010 --> 00:21:07,700
then cabling all this stuff together.

413
00:21:07,700 --> 00:21:09,500
So we'll get a chance to
see all that coming up.

414
00:21:09,500 --> 00:21:10,392
Stay tuned.

415
00:21:10,392 --> 00:21:12,434
We'll be back with more.

416
00:21:12,434 --> 00:21:17,470
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Virtual Switches
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:11,950
In this video we're gonna take a look at
the virtual switching inside of GNS3.

3
00:00:11,950 --> 00:00:16,215
Now GNS3's real power is
on the routing side, right.

4
00:00:16,215 --> 00:00:19,220
Sysco routers, Juniper routers,
ASAs, all that stuff.

5
00:00:19,220 --> 00:00:21,730
It's really amazing,
you get a lot of stuff.

6
00:00:21,730 --> 00:00:27,040
Really doesn't do any kind
of switch emulation, right?

7
00:00:27,040 --> 00:00:28,270
Doesn't do switch platform.

8
00:00:28,270 --> 00:00:29,130
It's just not done,

9
00:00:29,130 --> 00:00:32,690
and the main reason is switches have
a lot of proprietary hardware in them.

10
00:00:32,690 --> 00:00:35,280
As they are doing layer two
switching between ports,

11
00:00:35,280 --> 00:00:39,580
that just doesn't lend itself
to being emulated very well.

12
00:00:39,580 --> 00:00:42,380
I don't know of any products
out there that do that.

13
00:00:42,380 --> 00:00:45,870
On G&S3, what they did is they
created their own switches,

14
00:00:45,870 --> 00:00:47,410
which we don't really mess with much.

15
00:00:47,410 --> 00:00:51,840
We drop them out into our topology, and
we apply a configuration, if needed.

16
00:00:51,840 --> 00:00:55,220
If all I need is a straight up layer
two switch with nothing special,

17
00:00:55,220 --> 00:00:58,600
I can go under my switching menu here,
find ethernet switch,

18
00:00:58,600 --> 00:01:00,330
drag it out here and drop it.

19
00:01:00,330 --> 00:01:03,680
Now I've got a switch, and I can
start to plug my routers into it, and

20
00:01:03,680 --> 00:01:05,940
PCs and so on, all right.

21
00:01:05,940 --> 00:01:09,210
The switch will grow as
I plug things into it.

22
00:01:09,210 --> 00:01:11,650
So if I plug five things in,
it will have five ports.

23
00:01:11,650 --> 00:01:13,810
If I plug ten things in it,
they'll have ten ports.

24
00:01:13,810 --> 00:01:16,260
For the most part,
that may be all you need.

25
00:01:16,260 --> 00:01:19,250
You throw the switch out, and
you never mess with it again.

26
00:01:19,250 --> 00:01:20,313
That's it, all right.

27
00:01:20,313 --> 00:01:22,666
But there are some advanced
features in there.

28
00:01:22,666 --> 00:01:27,250
If you right-click on the switch, you'll
see configure, and inside of configure

29
00:01:27,250 --> 00:01:29,930
you can pull up the switch configuration,
and you can add the ports.

30
00:01:29,930 --> 00:01:32,140
See how mine started out with eight ports?

31
00:01:32,140 --> 00:01:33,700
So I can go and I can add more.

32
00:01:33,700 --> 00:01:36,570
If I wanted to get it set up with 12
ports from the very beginning, right,

33
00:01:36,570 --> 00:01:40,030
I could come in here and
pick my ports, and start to add them.

34
00:01:40,030 --> 00:01:45,290
The other thing is, these ports are all
set up to be in VLAN 1 as an access port.

35
00:01:45,290 --> 00:01:47,950
So it's just one big switch,
one big collision and

36
00:01:47,950 --> 00:01:49,640
broadcast domain, and that's it.

37
00:01:49,640 --> 00:01:54,220
I'm sorry, it's multiple collision
domains, but one big broadcast domain.

38
00:01:54,220 --> 00:01:56,900
And it's It's just there,
you plug your machines in and you're done.

39
00:01:56,900 --> 00:01:59,210
But if you're gonna be
working with trunking.

40
00:01:59,210 --> 00:02:02,530
You know, if you want to do router on
a stick, for example, where you have one

41
00:02:02,530 --> 00:02:05,570
connection running to the router, and
you want to break it up into VLANs.

42
00:02:05,570 --> 00:02:09,730
Well, you need to tell the switch to
carry more than one VLAN on that port.

43
00:02:09,730 --> 00:02:12,480
And the default configuration
doesn't do that.

44
00:02:12,480 --> 00:02:15,620
So you might wanna come in and
change the switch.

45
00:02:15,620 --> 00:02:19,500
Now it doesn't really let you
change a port that already exists.

46
00:02:19,500 --> 00:02:24,330
So if we want to get rid of one of
these ports, you can click on it and

47
00:02:24,330 --> 00:02:28,240
make a change, but if you try and,
here if I change this port

48
00:02:28,240 --> 00:02:32,560
From an access to an 802.1q trunk,
and hit Add, there it goes.

49
00:02:32,560 --> 00:02:35,250
It updates it, and
now it's reflecting that it's 802.1q.

50
00:02:35,250 --> 00:02:38,190
You can go through and
do that for each of these,

51
00:02:38,190 --> 00:02:42,280
to make them trunks, but sometimes it'll
add a new port down there at the end.

52
00:02:42,280 --> 00:02:46,100
So you gotta be aware of which port is
showing up, In this case it's this one.

53
00:02:46,100 --> 00:02:49,550
So if you want to modify an existing port,
you've gotta double click on it, so

54
00:02:49,550 --> 00:02:51,890
that this screen updates to
reflect the new values, and

55
00:02:51,890 --> 00:02:53,920
then you can modify it, all right.

56
00:02:53,920 --> 00:02:57,360
So if I want to have two
trunks from my routers,

57
00:02:57,360 --> 00:03:01,160
I can modify those ports and
now I've got two 802.1Q trunks.

58
00:03:01,160 --> 00:03:05,930
Now there's still a VLAN value,
that's gonna be the native VLAN.

59
00:03:05,930 --> 00:03:08,790
These guys both have
a native VLAN of VLAN1.

60
00:03:08,790 --> 00:03:10,490
That's exactly what I want right?

61
00:03:10,490 --> 00:03:11,330
Normally.

62
00:03:11,330 --> 00:03:14,970
But in your labs, if you're gonna be
using a native VLAN of something else,

63
00:03:14,970 --> 00:03:17,210
you might need to come in and
adjust that here.

64
00:03:17,210 --> 00:03:20,990
So maybe I want VLAN 10
to be my native VLAN.

65
00:03:20,990 --> 00:03:22,230
So I can modify that here.

66
00:03:22,230 --> 00:03:26,758
So now these are 802.1Q trunks,
with a native VLAN of VLAN 10.

67
00:03:26,758 --> 00:03:31,420
My other ports,I might want them to be on
different vlans too, but not be trunks.

68
00:03:31,420 --> 00:03:37,700
So I might say that, maybe these
other ports here are on VLAN ten.

69
00:03:37,700 --> 00:03:40,050
So I'll go and pump them over to VLAN ten,

70
00:03:40,050 --> 00:03:44,770
but the other guys maybe I
want them to be on VLAN two.

71
00:03:46,010 --> 00:03:48,240
So I can come in and I can change that.

72
00:03:48,240 --> 00:03:49,750
And set the VLAN information.

73
00:03:49,750 --> 00:03:52,520
Now we're not really learning
much about Sysco here,

74
00:03:52,520 --> 00:03:55,750
because well we're not using
the Sysco iOS or anything.

75
00:03:55,750 --> 00:03:57,400
But at least we have that functionality.

76
00:03:57,400 --> 00:03:59,120
Believe me it's better than nothing.

77
00:03:59,120 --> 00:04:02,320
What we used to have was, you'd have to
bring up a router with one of those 16

78
00:04:02,320 --> 00:04:05,550
port switch cards in it, and
do this stuff inside of the router.

79
00:04:05,550 --> 00:04:09,630
Which works, but even that is not like
a traditional Sysco switch, so it

80
00:04:09,630 --> 00:04:14,160
doesn't give you a proper representation
of what's on the exam for CCNA and CCNP.

81
00:04:14,160 --> 00:04:16,090
It's just not a good solution.

82
00:04:16,090 --> 00:04:18,530
So here at least we get
a switch that works.

83
00:04:18,530 --> 00:04:20,140
We can provide the functionality we need.

84
00:04:20,140 --> 00:04:23,560
Now we can plug our routers in,
and they can start to work.

85
00:04:23,560 --> 00:04:24,190
All right?

86
00:04:24,190 --> 00:04:27,750
Now I'm gonna change this
native VLAN back to VLAN1.

87
00:04:27,750 --> 00:04:32,080
I don't like to use a different
native VLAN if I don't have to.

88
00:04:32,080 --> 00:04:33,600
So I'll just put that back
to the way it was, but

89
00:04:33,600 --> 00:04:36,980
I'll leave these access ports
on VLAN10 and VLAN2, all right.

90
00:04:36,980 --> 00:04:40,585
Now we're where we plug
in our workstations,

91
00:04:40,585 --> 00:04:44,500
we'll need to be aware of which
ports they get plugged into to.

92
00:04:44,500 --> 00:04:45,100
You don't have to.

93
00:04:45,100 --> 00:04:47,720
You can plug them in and
have it use the first available.

94
00:04:47,720 --> 00:04:49,900
But since our ports now have
different configurations,

95
00:04:49,900 --> 00:04:52,240
we'll want to be very particular
about what we're plugging in to.

96
00:04:52,240 --> 00:04:54,450
I've got an eight port switch.

97
00:04:54,450 --> 00:04:56,890
What happens if I plug
a ninth machine into it?

98
00:04:56,890 --> 00:05:01,330
It'll add a ninth port,
which will be an access port on VLAN one.

99
00:05:01,330 --> 00:05:05,880
That's the default configuration for
a switch inside of GNS3.

100
00:05:05,880 --> 00:05:07,820
You've got some other options like a hub.

101
00:05:07,820 --> 00:05:09,710
If you want to bring a hub in you can.

102
00:05:09,710 --> 00:05:12,230
The hub obviously doesn't have
as many options as a switch,

103
00:05:12,230 --> 00:05:13,690
because well it's a hub.

104
00:05:13,690 --> 00:05:15,810
It doesn't look at your data.

105
00:05:15,810 --> 00:05:18,040
We've got ATM bridges and switches,

106
00:05:18,040 --> 00:05:20,250
if you want to learn about
asynchronous transfer mode.

107
00:05:20,250 --> 00:05:22,270
It's not really on any
of the exams anymore, so

108
00:05:22,270 --> 00:05:24,180
most people don't worry about that one.

109
00:05:24,180 --> 00:05:25,760
Frame relay though.

110
00:05:25,760 --> 00:05:30,610
If you wanna set up frame relay on your
network, you could throw in a router with

111
00:05:30,610 --> 00:05:33,760
a bunch of serial ports on it, and
configure it to be a frame relay switch.

112
00:05:33,760 --> 00:05:35,180
You can certainly do that.

113
00:05:35,180 --> 00:05:37,940
Or, you could just use
this guy right here.

114
00:05:37,940 --> 00:05:42,850
Bring it out, and you'll see here
where we can define our DLCI mappings.

115
00:05:42,850 --> 00:05:45,930
So we can create all the mappings that
the telephone company would normally do,

116
00:05:45,930 --> 00:05:48,280
and configure our routers to use it.

117
00:05:48,280 --> 00:05:50,306
So I might have port one,

118
00:05:50,306 --> 00:05:55,720
with a DLCI of 101 connected to port two,
with a DLCI of 202.

119
00:05:55,720 --> 00:05:59,560
And then I can come in and
start mapping other ones that I want.

120
00:05:59,560 --> 00:06:05,127
I might have port one with
a DLCI 103 connecting

121
00:06:05,127 --> 00:06:10,420
with port three, with a DLCI of 303.

122
00:06:10,420 --> 00:06:11,020
Right?

123
00:06:11,020 --> 00:06:12,310
And then continuing on.

124
00:06:12,310 --> 00:06:16,260
So I'm setting up router one
to basically be like my hub.

125
00:06:16,260 --> 00:06:18,910
And all of these other
sites to be my spokes.

126
00:06:18,910 --> 00:06:24,720
So I can go through and enter in all the
DLCI information that relates to those.

127
00:06:24,720 --> 00:06:26,080
Building it up here.

128
00:06:26,080 --> 00:06:28,490
You can do it on the router if you want,
or you can do it right here.

129
00:06:28,490 --> 00:06:30,600
It's just kind of a canned
frame relay switch.

130
00:06:32,560 --> 00:06:34,770
Alright, the last one here
is EtherSwitch router,

131
00:06:34,770 --> 00:06:37,360
and that would be a layer three switch.

132
00:06:37,360 --> 00:06:40,960
If we drag that one and throw it out here,
this one's a little bit different than

133
00:06:40,960 --> 00:06:43,370
the other ones,
because it has routing built into it.

134
00:06:43,370 --> 00:06:44,970
It's a little more complex.

135
00:06:44,970 --> 00:06:47,030
If we pull up its configuration,

136
00:06:47,030 --> 00:06:50,320
you'll see that we've got options that
basically look like a router, right.

137
00:06:50,320 --> 00:06:53,340
We see our mid plane and MPE, our memory,

138
00:06:53,340 --> 00:06:57,630
our slots where we pick how much stuff
we've got, and some advanced settings.

139
00:06:57,630 --> 00:07:01,980
But for the most part it's like a actual
router, and if you start it up.

140
00:07:04,890 --> 00:07:07,230
You can actually console into this one.

141
00:07:07,230 --> 00:07:10,650
And it'll come up, and
you'll see configuration in here that is,

142
00:07:10,650 --> 00:07:14,340
based in iOS CSO Firehop Sysco
3725 router,

143
00:07:14,340 --> 00:07:20,140
it's really just a 3725 router with
a 16 port switch card stuck in it.

144
00:07:20,140 --> 00:07:23,070
So it looks like a switch,
but it is a router.

145
00:07:23,070 --> 00:07:25,480
That's all its doing right
there to provide that.

146
00:07:25,480 --> 00:07:29,210
And if I do a show ip interface brief,

147
00:07:30,310 --> 00:07:34,020
there's those 16 ports all
showing up right there.

148
00:07:34,020 --> 00:07:39,520
And so their fast ethernet 1/0-15,
and I've got a vLAN interface.

149
00:07:39,520 --> 00:07:43,280
So, now I'm kinda configuring this
more like in a Sysco environment.

150
00:07:43,280 --> 00:07:45,900
But it is a router, not a switch, and so

151
00:07:45,900 --> 00:07:49,920
there's some things that just
don't work right, like VTP, and

152
00:07:49,920 --> 00:07:55,020
a lot of the spanning tree functionality
just doesn't work right on this system.

153
00:07:55,020 --> 00:07:58,500
So you get some of the Sysco
functionality but not all.

154
00:07:58,500 --> 00:07:59,800
I typically don't use this,

155
00:07:59,800 --> 00:08:03,210
just cuz I know it's somewhat
inconsistent, but it is there.

156
00:08:03,210 --> 00:08:05,010
It's a resource available for you.

157
00:08:05,010 --> 00:08:09,825
[SOUND] All right well,
once you get your switches out here,

158
00:08:09,825 --> 00:08:14,750
and everything's kind of arranged
the way that you want it.

159
00:08:14,750 --> 00:08:17,220
Trying to get rid of these extra devices.

160
00:08:17,220 --> 00:08:19,000
Now, we've got our equipment.

161
00:08:19,000 --> 00:08:21,600
We just need to cable it up and
get it running, all right?

162
00:08:21,600 --> 00:08:24,800
So, we'll get a chance to see
cabling in the next video.

163
00:08:24,800 --> 00:08:26,280
Be sure to stay tuned for that one.

164
00:08:26,280 --> 00:08:26,780
It's coming up next.

165
00:08:28,840 --> 00:08:29,585
Next.

166
00:08:29,585 --> 00:08:34,224
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Cabling Your Equipment
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:02,448 --> 00:00:07,487
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,487 --> 00:00:10,162
So you've seen how to add routers and
switches and

3
00:00:10,162 --> 00:00:12,740
other equipment into your topology.

4
00:00:12,740 --> 00:00:16,320
Now, we need to cable it together so
we can actually use this stuff.

5
00:00:16,320 --> 00:00:19,030
So that's our next step is
getting things cabled together.

6
00:00:19,030 --> 00:00:22,098
Fortunately, it really couldn't be
any easier here inside of GNS3.

7
00:00:22,098 --> 00:00:24,090
When we wanna cable something,

8
00:00:24,090 --> 00:00:27,430
we have this little cable wizard
type option that we can use.

9
00:00:27,430 --> 00:00:27,950
It's pretty neat.

10
00:00:27,950 --> 00:00:29,570
Let me show you how it works.

11
00:00:29,570 --> 00:00:31,760
On the left side of the screen,
you'll see an icon here.

12
00:00:31,760 --> 00:00:36,780
It's supposed to look like an RJ45
jack and a cat 5 cable, or whatever.

13
00:00:36,780 --> 00:00:38,080
So you'll see that button there.

14
00:00:38,080 --> 00:00:40,310
This is your generic cable button.

15
00:00:40,310 --> 00:00:46,360
It will let you run any type of cable that
you want, be it Fast Ethernet or Gigabit.

16
00:00:46,360 --> 00:00:49,980
If you want it to be serial,
whatever, right?

17
00:00:49,980 --> 00:00:51,570
What it does is when you go to connect,

18
00:00:51,570 --> 00:00:54,860
it's gonna ask you what port
you're plugging into, and it will

19
00:00:54,860 --> 00:00:59,270
choose the appropriate cable type based on
the port that you've selected, all right?

20
00:00:59,270 --> 00:01:01,711
So let's say I wanna take Router 1 and

21
00:01:01,711 --> 00:01:05,153
plug its first interface into Switch 1,
all right?

22
00:01:05,153 --> 00:01:10,070
Well I can click on Router 1 and
I'll get a list of all of my ports.

23
00:01:10,070 --> 00:01:14,538
And on this router, I've got two
Fast Ethernet ports, fa0/0 and

24
00:01:14,538 --> 00:01:18,100
0/1, and
then I've got serial 1/0 through 3.

25
00:01:18,100 --> 00:01:19,865
I've got a four port
serial card in this one.

26
00:01:19,865 --> 00:01:26,620
I'm gonna choose fa0/0, and now it's just
asking me where I wanna plug it into.

27
00:01:26,620 --> 00:01:28,040
And so I'll go down here to the switch and

28
00:01:28,040 --> 00:01:32,213
click, and that's gonna let me pick
which port I'll plug into on the switch.

29
00:01:32,213 --> 00:01:32,910
And I'll pick Port 1, all right?

30
00:01:32,910 --> 00:01:36,920
Now because this is my first connection,

31
00:01:36,920 --> 00:01:40,300
it's now realizing that I'm gonna have
these devices networked together.

32
00:01:40,300 --> 00:01:43,990
And in Windows, in order to do that,
we need to clear the Windows firewall.

33
00:01:43,990 --> 00:01:46,912
So it's asking if we can add
that rule to the firewall.

34
00:01:46,912 --> 00:01:49,920
I'm gonna go ahead and
do it, and hit allow access.

35
00:01:49,920 --> 00:01:54,550
Now the cable is there, the router is on,
so the link goes green.

36
00:01:54,550 --> 00:01:55,160
I've got link lights.

37
00:01:55,160 --> 00:01:57,900
That's what these little circles
are right here are my link lights,

38
00:01:57,900 --> 00:02:00,210
to let me know that I've got a connection.

39
00:02:00,210 --> 00:02:03,030
I could come over here to Router 2 and
plug it in.

40
00:02:03,030 --> 00:02:07,970
I'll do it f0/0 and
plug that into the switch on Port 2.

41
00:02:07,970 --> 00:02:09,730
And now there they go, right?

42
00:02:09,730 --> 00:02:11,580
Off and ready to go.

43
00:02:11,580 --> 00:02:13,710
When you're done running those cables
you just click the button over

44
00:02:13,710 --> 00:02:16,670
here on the left screen again,
and now you're ready to work.

45
00:02:16,670 --> 00:02:19,640
Now remember when I plug those guys in,
I plug them into Ports 1 and 2.

46
00:02:19,640 --> 00:02:23,622
And if I double click on my switch,
remember how I set Port 1 and

47
00:02:23,622 --> 00:02:24,720
2 to be trunks.

48
00:02:24,720 --> 00:02:28,140
I need to remember that so that I can
go and set up router on a stick or

49
00:02:28,140 --> 00:02:29,700
whatever it is that I wanna do.

50
00:02:29,700 --> 00:02:30,290
But otherwise,

51
00:02:30,290 --> 00:02:34,440
they're plugged in, and they're gonna be
on VLAN1 if they don't build up a trunk.

52
00:02:34,440 --> 00:02:37,330
And they should be able to see each
other right through that switch.

53
00:02:37,330 --> 00:02:40,480
I can then go ahead and plug other
devices in and start to grow my network.

54
00:02:41,580 --> 00:02:44,540
Now, just for kicks I threw in
a frame relay switch up here.

55
00:02:44,540 --> 00:02:48,480
And if I wanna do serial connections
to that, I can come over here and

56
00:02:48,480 --> 00:02:50,440
click my cable button again.

57
00:02:50,440 --> 00:02:53,510
And on Router 1 this time I'll just
pick one of my serial connections.

58
00:02:53,510 --> 00:02:55,370
I'll do serial 1/0.

59
00:02:55,370 --> 00:02:58,010
And I can run that up here
to my frame relay switch,

60
00:02:58,010 --> 00:02:59,280
where I'll plug it into Port 1.

61
00:02:59,280 --> 00:03:01,397
And I'll do the same thing
over here on Router 2.

62
00:03:01,397 --> 00:03:06,590
I'll take its serial 1/0 and
plug it into Port 2, all right?

63
00:03:06,590 --> 00:03:08,790
I could also run directly
between the routers.

64
00:03:08,790 --> 00:03:11,230
I'll take serial 1/3 and

65
00:03:11,230 --> 00:03:15,780
run it over to Router 2 on serial 1/3 and
there we go, all right?

66
00:03:15,780 --> 00:03:17,970
So now I've started to
build out that topology,

67
00:03:17,970 --> 00:03:22,440
I can see what connections are linked,
and I can start to experiment and learn.

68
00:03:22,440 --> 00:03:24,410
You can run multiple connections too.

69
00:03:24,410 --> 00:03:26,640
You might be testing redundancy.

70
00:03:26,640 --> 00:03:30,160
So I might wanna run another
connection between these two routers.

71
00:03:30,160 --> 00:03:34,800
I'll connect serial 1/2 over to Router 2,
serial 1/2.

72
00:03:34,800 --> 00:03:37,740
When you do that it'll
stack the cables together.

73
00:03:37,740 --> 00:03:41,220
So now I can see I've got redundant
links between that router.

74
00:03:41,220 --> 00:03:46,364
Really cool if you're trying to do things
like link aggregation, or if you're

75
00:03:46,364 --> 00:03:51,690
trying to see equal cost load balancing
inside of EIGRP, or something like that.

76
00:03:51,690 --> 00:03:53,547
Really nice to have those
multiple links to test with.

77
00:03:53,547 --> 00:03:59,480
PPP/Multilink, that's another one where
you need two serial links to do it.

78
00:03:59,480 --> 00:04:01,540
Any of those technologies
you'll run more than one link.

79
00:04:01,540 --> 00:04:04,980
So, it's really just limited to you and
the connections that you wanna run.

80
00:04:04,980 --> 00:04:07,410
You cable it up, and then you're done.

81
00:04:07,410 --> 00:04:10,190
Now the cables actually do have
a life of their own in GNS3.

82
00:04:10,190 --> 00:04:12,809
When we start to work with our equipment,

83
00:04:13,910 --> 00:04:16,270
you can float over these to
get the information about it.

84
00:04:16,270 --> 00:04:19,540
It'll tell you the two end
points on that cable, right?

85
00:04:19,540 --> 00:04:21,720
Router 2, Router 1, whatever.

86
00:04:21,720 --> 00:04:26,025
And later on we'll see where you can right
click on these and choose start capturing.

87
00:04:26,025 --> 00:04:28,430
And that'll fire up Wireshark,

88
00:04:28,430 --> 00:04:32,580
and allow us to capture all
the traffic crossing that cable.

89
00:04:32,580 --> 00:04:35,090
And that's really cool if you
wanna see the packets and

90
00:04:35,090 --> 00:04:37,305
communications going on
between those routers.

91
00:04:37,305 --> 00:04:39,290
There's communications going on right now.

92
00:04:39,290 --> 00:04:43,220
Those serial links come up,
Cisco routers run CDP by default,

93
00:04:43,220 --> 00:04:47,210
Cisco Discovery Protocol, so
those packets should be passing along.

94
00:04:47,210 --> 00:04:52,090
Although, just because the link is up
doesn't mean the interface is active.

95
00:04:52,090 --> 00:04:54,960
Cisco routers shut their
ports down by default.

96
00:04:54,960 --> 00:04:57,530
So these ports are probably
still administratively shutdown.

97
00:04:57,530 --> 00:05:01,720
I guess we could see that real quick if we
fired one end up and looked at it here.

98
00:05:04,100 --> 00:05:05,519
And we can see their status.

99
00:05:06,630 --> 00:05:08,840
Yeah, they're all
administratively shut down.

100
00:05:08,840 --> 00:05:10,900
But their links should be up, and so

101
00:05:10,900 --> 00:05:17,090
we could get into our configuration and
can I do a range command on a router?

102
00:05:17,090 --> 00:05:17,660
Sure can, all right.

103
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:24,610
And I'll just issue some no shutdown
commands to bring those up.

104
00:05:31,528 --> 00:05:33,565
And let me remember what
my serial interfaces are.

105
00:05:33,565 --> 00:05:37,635
1/0 through 3 I guess would
make it a little bit happier.

106
00:05:41,825 --> 00:05:44,355
That range command is
always a sensitive one.

107
00:05:44,355 --> 00:05:46,975
Sometimes it'll take your input,
sometimes it won't.

108
00:05:46,975 --> 00:05:48,185
All right, well,
I'll just do this by hand.

109
00:05:48,185 --> 00:05:51,545
Not that big of a deal.

110
00:05:51,545 --> 00:05:54,805
But we'll start bringing these up, and
what we'll see is that we should be

111
00:05:54,805 --> 00:05:58,980
getting link up messages, because,
well, the links are up, right?

112
00:05:58,980 --> 00:05:59,780
We've got link lights.

113
00:05:59,780 --> 00:06:02,920
The other side is maybe or
maybe not configured, but

114
00:06:02,920 --> 00:06:05,360
those links are coming up, they're happy.

115
00:06:05,360 --> 00:06:06,180
Now we're ready to work.

116
00:06:06,180 --> 00:06:08,820
Now we can get into our routers and
really start to do things,

117
00:06:08,820 --> 00:06:14,270
start to experiment around, and
see how things are going, all right?

118
00:06:14,270 --> 00:06:16,920
One little word of advice to mention here.

119
00:06:16,920 --> 00:06:19,590
These ethernet ports,
see how like my fa0/1?

120
00:06:19,590 --> 00:06:24,870
I just turned it on and
it's showing as up up, right?

121
00:06:24,870 --> 00:06:29,750
But if I go back here and look,
my fa0/1, what is it plugged into?

122
00:06:29,750 --> 00:06:32,510
Well, I can't really tell right here.

123
00:06:32,510 --> 00:06:34,310
On the right side,
I can go to Router 1 and

124
00:06:34,310 --> 00:06:37,020
expand it and
it'll tell me what's plugged in.

125
00:06:37,020 --> 00:06:40,115
Notice fa0/1 is not on the list.

126
00:06:40,115 --> 00:06:44,179
0/0 was run to a switch, s1/0, s1/2, s1/3.

127
00:06:44,179 --> 00:06:48,881
But fa0/1 is not in the list.

128
00:06:48,881 --> 00:06:52,708
How can it be up with a link light
if it's not even in the list?

129
00:06:52,708 --> 00:06:57,510
Well, in GNS3 when you bring an interface
up, it'll always show a link light.

130
00:06:57,510 --> 00:07:01,500
So you'll always have Layer 1 and
Layer 2 registering as being connected,

131
00:07:01,500 --> 00:07:05,010
even though you're not necessarily
able to communicate across that line.

132
00:07:05,010 --> 00:07:06,570
So just be aware of that.

133
00:07:06,570 --> 00:07:07,700
If you shut the interface down,

134
00:07:07,700 --> 00:07:11,870
it will go down, but the link will
always show up inside of the router.

135
00:07:11,870 --> 00:07:13,460
It's kind of one of
the limitations that we have.

136
00:07:15,010 --> 00:07:17,290
All right, but other than that,
that's the cabling.

137
00:07:17,290 --> 00:07:19,160
You can always change
it after the fact too.

138
00:07:19,160 --> 00:07:21,420
If you hover over one of the link lights,

139
00:07:21,420 --> 00:07:25,200
you can hold your mouse button down and
click to move the link.

140
00:07:25,200 --> 00:07:28,280
Actually it's not letting me move that
one, probably cuz the router's on.

141
00:07:28,280 --> 00:07:31,840
You can always right click on it and
delete it too, and remove that cable and

142
00:07:31,840 --> 00:07:32,630
then rerun it.

143
00:07:34,070 --> 00:07:37,150
And so maybe I wanna plug it
into a different port this time.

144
00:07:37,150 --> 00:07:39,360
And so I can choose that
different port and run it.

145
00:07:39,360 --> 00:07:43,280
So a lot of this stuff can be changed,
re-mapped, moved around however you need.

146
00:07:43,280 --> 00:07:43,829
Really cool stuff.

147
00:07:44,960 --> 00:07:48,980
All right, well that's probably enough
on cabling, so we'll wrap it up there.

148
00:07:48,980 --> 00:07:52,770
We've got more videos coming on how to
work with GNS3, so stay tuned for those.

149
00:07:52,770 --> 00:07:53,954
I hope you guys enjoyed this one.

150
00:07:53,954 --> 00:08:01,439
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Connecting To Your Routers
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,935
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,935 --> 00:00:10,708
So now you've built your topology,
you've got your routers out,

3
00:00:10,708 --> 00:00:13,091
you've got your switches out,
and all that's in place,

4
00:00:13,091 --> 00:00:15,781
you've started them up and
you're ready to get to work, right.

5
00:00:15,781 --> 00:00:18,890
So, how do we connect into
these devices to work with it?

6
00:00:18,890 --> 00:00:21,820
I know I've already showed you one way in
an earlier video which is connecting to

7
00:00:21,820 --> 00:00:23,890
the console of the device.

8
00:00:23,890 --> 00:00:26,320
And for our initial setup that's
normally what we're going to do.

9
00:00:26,320 --> 00:00:28,450
The easiest way to that is like this.

10
00:00:28,450 --> 00:00:33,210
You just right click on the device you
want to manage and you choose Console.

11
00:00:33,210 --> 00:00:35,660
When you choose that it'll
open up the console port.

12
00:00:35,660 --> 00:00:37,130
Just opening up a putty window.

13
00:00:37,130 --> 00:00:41,160
And here I am ready to work
with that particular system.

14
00:00:41,160 --> 00:00:44,110
So there we go exciting right?

15
00:00:44,110 --> 00:00:46,950
Now, if you just fired up
eight different routers and

16
00:00:46,950 --> 00:00:50,110
you want to connect to all eight
console ports, you can actually

17
00:00:50,110 --> 00:00:54,950
use the big console button up here in your
task bar or whatever we want to call that.

18
00:00:54,950 --> 00:00:59,930
When you choose that, its got the option
to console connect to all devices and

19
00:00:59,930 --> 00:01:03,350
that'll fire up a console window not
just to router one, but to router two.

20
00:01:03,350 --> 00:01:05,870
See how it's just cascading
them on my screen.

21
00:01:05,870 --> 00:01:08,170
So I've got each of them
available right here.

22
00:01:08,170 --> 00:01:10,910
A quick and
easy way to whip open those consoles.

23
00:01:10,910 --> 00:01:15,230
Be aware, that just like a real console
port, only one person can be connected at

24
00:01:15,230 --> 00:01:20,420
a time, so you can't open more than one
console connection to the same router.

25
00:01:20,420 --> 00:01:22,420
It won't let you do that.

26
00:01:22,420 --> 00:01:24,220
The second one just won't connect.

27
00:01:24,220 --> 00:01:29,330
So if I try and console in here,
there's my valid console window.

28
00:01:29,330 --> 00:01:30,920
I'll just move it to the background.

29
00:01:30,920 --> 00:01:37,090
And if I try and console in again, what
we'll get is some screen interruption.

30
00:01:37,090 --> 00:01:39,220
See that little corruption that we got?

31
00:01:39,220 --> 00:01:41,940
And that's us jumping into
an existing session and

32
00:01:41,940 --> 00:01:44,350
effectively kicking out the old one.

33
00:01:44,350 --> 00:01:45,650
So you've gotta be careful with that.

34
00:01:45,650 --> 00:01:47,460
The two will conflict with each other.

35
00:01:47,460 --> 00:01:50,760
Just keep one console
connection open per device.

36
00:01:50,760 --> 00:01:54,500
But you can have ten console windows
open at ten different devices.

37
00:01:54,500 --> 00:01:55,310
That's perfectly fine.

38
00:01:56,600 --> 00:01:58,940
Now, there is another neat thing.

39
00:01:58,940 --> 00:02:03,990
What if I want to run
GNS3 on one computer, but

40
00:02:03,990 --> 00:02:06,740
I wanna use a different
computer to work from.

41
00:02:06,740 --> 00:02:10,540
So for example, maybe I've got a desktop
machine at home that's really powerful and

42
00:02:10,540 --> 00:02:12,300
I wanna run my routers from there.

43
00:02:12,300 --> 00:02:14,870
But then I wanna sit in
the living room on my laptop and

44
00:02:14,870 --> 00:02:16,330
actually work with this stuff.

45
00:02:16,330 --> 00:02:18,570
My laptop might not be powerful
enough to run all the different

46
00:02:18,570 --> 00:02:19,750
routers that I've got.

47
00:02:19,750 --> 00:02:23,900
Well, you can remotely connect
into these routers also.

48
00:02:23,900 --> 00:02:27,340
If you right click on one of the routers
you'll see the option in here

49
00:02:27,340 --> 00:02:30,060
change console port.

50
00:02:30,060 --> 00:02:34,620
Every one of these has their console
mapped to a TCP port number.

51
00:02:34,620 --> 00:02:36,740
And if you look at it.

52
00:02:36,740 --> 00:02:40,060
I must restart, oh it's just a warning
you have to restart if you change it.

53
00:02:40,060 --> 00:02:44,720
But I can see that router one has
a console port number of 2101.

54
00:02:44,720 --> 00:02:46,390
All right.

55
00:02:46,390 --> 00:02:49,280
So what I can do is,
assuming this is open in my firewall, so

56
00:02:49,280 --> 00:02:52,220
I'd want to go into Windows Firewall and
open up port 2101,

57
00:02:52,220 --> 00:02:55,700
but then I can go to any other
machine on my internal network.

58
00:02:55,700 --> 00:03:01,780
And if I telnet to this computer on
port 2101, I'll see that console right.

59
00:03:01,780 --> 00:03:02,820
Let me show you that.

60
00:03:02,820 --> 00:03:03,530
If I go and

61
00:03:03,530 --> 00:03:07,220
I'm just going to close this other console
window because I don't want conflicts.

62
00:03:08,710 --> 00:03:12,800
We're conflict free here,
I think that's the Starbucks motto.

63
00:03:12,800 --> 00:03:18,280
So I'm just gonna fire up a command prompt
here, and I'm gonna do Telnet 127.0.0.1,

64
00:03:18,280 --> 00:03:20,900
connecting to myself, on port 2101.

65
00:03:22,630 --> 00:03:24,870
When I do that, there I am.

66
00:03:24,870 --> 00:03:29,600
I'm connected to that router and I can
start to work with it and everything.

67
00:03:29,600 --> 00:03:33,280
I lost my cool amber screen
that I had in putty.

68
00:03:33,280 --> 00:03:36,360
But here am I am and
I can work with this system.

69
00:03:36,360 --> 00:03:41,050
So you can run GNS three on one computer
but actually work from another one.

70
00:03:41,050 --> 00:03:42,740
And still access the consoles, right.

71
00:03:42,740 --> 00:03:46,360
So I can get in here I can
work with the system and

72
00:03:46,360 --> 00:03:48,570
it's just like I'm plugged
directly into the console.

73
00:03:48,570 --> 00:03:50,010
See all my interfaces are shut down but

74
00:03:50,010 --> 00:03:52,740
I'm still in because I'm
on the console port.

75
00:03:52,740 --> 00:03:55,800
And I used the command prompt
Telnet to get there but

76
00:03:55,800 --> 00:03:57,900
you could have used PuTTY, right?

77
00:03:57,900 --> 00:03:59,540
So I could have done
the same thing here and

78
00:03:59,540 --> 00:04:05,140
just pointed to my host, told it I was
doing Telnet, and change that port number.

79
00:04:05,140 --> 00:04:07,420
The other router is probably
2102 if I had to guess.

80
00:04:07,420 --> 00:04:10,030
And there it is.

81
00:04:10,030 --> 00:04:11,820
See in PuTTY, I've got my color change so

82
00:04:11,820 --> 00:04:14,200
it shows up at your end
connected to router two.

83
00:04:14,200 --> 00:04:18,690
And it shows my connection
right there on C2Y.

84
00:04:18,690 --> 00:04:20,930
I'm consoled in and I'm working with it.

85
00:04:20,930 --> 00:04:23,910
So a really cool thing to do there and
get connected.

86
00:04:23,910 --> 00:04:26,990
Now it does use Telnet,
which is not secure.

87
00:04:26,990 --> 00:04:29,540
But these routers should never be in
a production environment anyway, so

88
00:04:29,540 --> 00:04:31,010
that's not a big deal.

89
00:04:31,010 --> 00:04:33,940
This is for lab and test,
Telnet's more than adequate.

90
00:04:33,940 --> 00:04:37,720
If you do SSH, well now you've
gotta encrypt and decrypt traffic,

91
00:04:37,720 --> 00:04:40,630
which is gonna increase the CPU
loads on these routers.

92
00:04:40,630 --> 00:04:43,600
The more routers you have, the more of
a burden that places on your system.

93
00:04:43,600 --> 00:04:46,540
So just be aware,
from a performance standpoint,

94
00:04:46,540 --> 00:04:48,787
that you don't wanna go crazy with
things like encryption on these.

95
00:04:48,787 --> 00:04:55,160
Now, what if I wanna use
something like the Cisco SDM,

96
00:04:55,160 --> 00:04:59,920
the Security and Device Manager, the
graphical user interface for the router?

97
00:04:59,920 --> 00:05:03,840
Well, normally on a router, what you
would do is you would copy the SDM onto

98
00:05:03,840 --> 00:05:07,410
the Flash of the router, and then you can
browse through the router's web interface.

99
00:05:07,410 --> 00:05:09,470
Or the router's already got
a web interface, doesn't it.

100
00:05:09,470 --> 00:05:12,820
I could just browse it and
use that from my PC.

101
00:05:12,820 --> 00:05:17,350
Well, this network that we've
just created is isolated.

102
00:05:17,350 --> 00:05:19,690
It's inside of GNS3 and that's it.

103
00:05:19,690 --> 00:05:25,140
There's no way for my desktop
computer to connect to that router.

104
00:05:25,140 --> 00:05:28,200
For example, if I,
let me fire up my command prompt again.

105
00:05:28,200 --> 00:05:33,290
My IP address for
my system is 10.1.230.243.

106
00:05:33,290 --> 00:05:36,110
Right, that's my IP address.

107
00:05:36,110 --> 00:05:41,060
And if I take this router and
let me just connect to it's console here.

108
00:05:45,550 --> 00:05:50,430
And connect to it's interface,
and I'll give

109
00:05:50,430 --> 00:05:55,220
it an IP address of 10.1.230.244, so
it's just the IP right after mine.

110
00:05:59,080 --> 00:06:01,150
I show that interface is up.

111
00:06:01,150 --> 00:06:03,420
And I've got that IP address.

112
00:06:03,420 --> 00:06:09,180
But if I try and ping my laptop,
it's gonna fail.

113
00:06:09,180 --> 00:06:14,250
And that's because GNS3 creates its
own isolated, separate environment.

114
00:06:14,250 --> 00:06:16,460
That console port is the exception.

115
00:06:16,460 --> 00:06:20,150
It's mapped that console port to
a port number on our own machine, and

116
00:06:20,150 --> 00:06:21,900
that's why we're able to get it back.

117
00:06:21,900 --> 00:06:25,290
But we're not able to get to the network
interfaces through that port number,

118
00:06:25,290 --> 00:06:27,110
just the console.

119
00:06:27,110 --> 00:06:29,400
So, what if I actually do
wanna get to the router?

120
00:06:29,400 --> 00:06:32,750
What if I wanna be able to fire up
a web browser and hit the router?

121
00:06:32,750 --> 00:06:37,330
What we can do is we can create
a private network inside of a GNS3

122
00:06:37,330 --> 00:06:40,420
that's connected to a virtual
interface on our computer.

123
00:06:41,420 --> 00:06:45,420
It's a little bit complex, not the easiest
thing to do, but it's pretty neat and

124
00:06:45,420 --> 00:06:48,180
it does open up a whole new
realm of possibilities.

125
00:06:48,180 --> 00:06:51,310
You could run a TFTP server
on your workstation, and

126
00:06:51,310 --> 00:06:53,140
copy your configs back and forth.

127
00:06:53,140 --> 00:06:57,630
You could bring up a RADIUS server for
doing authentication and

128
00:06:57,630 --> 00:06:59,470
have the routers use that for
authentication.

129
00:06:59,470 --> 00:07:02,600
There's a lot of labs
that open themselves up

130
00:07:02,600 --> 00:07:06,350
as soon as you connect your own
PC into that virtual environment.

131
00:07:06,350 --> 00:07:07,720
All right, now I say PC.

132
00:07:07,720 --> 00:07:10,760
It's the same thing under Linux or Mac OS.

133
00:07:10,760 --> 00:07:14,080
We just need to get it attached
to a virtual interface.

134
00:07:15,250 --> 00:07:19,240
On the Windows side the easiest way to
do that is with a loopback adapter.

135
00:07:19,240 --> 00:07:20,810
If you're on a Linux machine or

136
00:07:20,810 --> 00:07:23,720
a Mac OS machine,
you already have a loopback adapter.

137
00:07:23,720 --> 00:07:24,440
They put one in.

138
00:07:24,440 --> 00:07:27,890
It's part of the The Unix definitions,
that they have that.

139
00:07:27,890 --> 00:07:29,130
In Windows, we don't.

140
00:07:29,130 --> 00:07:32,720
So I need to add one in to
be able to make use of it.

141
00:07:32,720 --> 00:07:36,931
The other thing is, I'm gonna want that
loopback adapter to show up in GNS3.

142
00:07:36,931 --> 00:07:40,960
GNS3 will not recognize
the loopback adapter in Windows

143
00:07:40,960 --> 00:07:43,810
unless you're running
it as an administrator.

144
00:07:43,810 --> 00:07:45,520
I didn't run this as an administrator.

145
00:07:45,520 --> 00:07:50,090
So if I want to see these routers
I'm gonna need to relaunch GNS3 and

146
00:07:50,090 --> 00:07:52,010
run it as an administrator.

147
00:07:52,010 --> 00:07:54,600
So I'm just going to stop it and
shut it down here.

148
00:07:54,600 --> 00:07:57,028
So I'm closing GNS3.

149
00:07:57,028 --> 00:08:02,109
I guess I could save my topology so
I don't have to redo it.

150
00:08:02,109 --> 00:08:04,290
So, we'll just call it my GNS3 Lab.

151
00:08:06,500 --> 00:08:08,130
All right, and

152
00:08:08,130 --> 00:08:12,860
what I'll do is go through the process
of adding in a loopback adapter.

153
00:08:12,860 --> 00:08:15,710
In Windows,
