connect.

379
00:20:47,140 --> 00:20:51,170
But if I did have the SDM, I could fire
up that GUI, point it to the router, and

380
00:20:51,170 --> 00:20:52,930
now I would be able to
work from it on my PC.

381
00:20:52,930 --> 00:20:58,440
And on my PC, I could create a FTP server
or TFTP server for transferring backups of

382
00:20:58,440 --> 00:21:03,480
configs, I could bring up a radius server
in a virtual machine if I wanted and

383
00:21:03,480 --> 00:21:07,040
attach it to that loop back, and
then they'd be able to see the routers.

384
00:21:07,040 --> 00:21:09,690
Now I've really opened up
the functionality here and

385
00:21:09,690 --> 00:21:11,280
I can get all sorts of stuff connected in.

386
00:21:11,280 --> 00:21:13,040
This is where the real fun starts, right?

387
00:21:13,040 --> 00:21:15,760
I can even provide internet access
to those routers if I need to,

388
00:21:15,760 --> 00:21:18,970
for them to be able to reach out and
do tests and things like that.

389
00:21:18,970 --> 00:21:21,090
But otherwise, I'm in here.

390
00:21:21,090 --> 00:21:25,290
A lot of these commands
are somewhat useless,

391
00:21:25,290 --> 00:21:28,270
because I don't have the QOS
device management installed.

392
00:21:28,270 --> 00:21:29,620
But it is nice.

393
00:21:29,620 --> 00:21:31,300
They show tech support for example,

394
00:21:31,300 --> 00:21:34,020
which dumps out a ton of
information about the router.

395
00:21:34,020 --> 00:21:37,200
We can bring that up and
see all sorts of good things in there.

396
00:21:37,200 --> 00:21:38,452
It's really neat, right?

397
00:21:38,452 --> 00:21:42,700
I've now got connectivity between
my workstation and the router.

398
00:21:42,700 --> 00:21:47,460
That means that I can do things like
connecting directly to the router, right?

399
00:21:47,460 --> 00:21:49,480
This is the console port right here.

400
00:21:49,480 --> 00:21:51,700
But maybe I wanna log
into the router itself,

401
00:21:51,700 --> 00:21:53,600
not going through the console port.

402
00:21:53,600 --> 00:21:57,600
So, well it's up, actually SSH is on,
so I should be able to SSH into it.

403
00:21:57,600 --> 00:21:58,720
Let me give that a shot.

404
00:21:58,720 --> 00:22:04,900
So I'm SSHing to 192.168.0.1 on port 22,
right?

405
00:22:04,900 --> 00:22:06,561
That's not the console,
I'm going to the actual router.

406
00:22:06,561 --> 00:22:12,670
And when I go and open that up,
It should hit it, there we go.

407
00:22:12,670 --> 00:22:14,500
Got my new key coming in.

408
00:22:14,500 --> 00:22:16,680
I'll log in as admin.

409
00:22:16,680 --> 00:22:19,750
Cisco123, and there we go.

410
00:22:19,750 --> 00:22:20,320
Oh shoot.

411
00:22:20,320 --> 00:22:21,155
I haven't [LAUGH].

412
00:22:21,155 --> 00:22:23,980
I haven't configured my
authorization piece yet, and so

413
00:22:23,980 --> 00:22:25,540
it's still giving me a little error there.

414
00:22:25,540 --> 00:22:27,170
But I'm in.

415
00:22:27,170 --> 00:22:30,000
I can work with the system and
if I do a show line,

416
00:22:30,000 --> 00:22:32,310
I'll see that I'm on one of the VTYs.

417
00:22:32,310 --> 00:22:36,780
My console is still open somewhere,
but I'm on a VTY right now.

418
00:22:36,780 --> 00:22:37,950
Actually, if I do show IP ssh.

419
00:22:41,791 --> 00:22:43,960
And show user.

420
00:22:43,960 --> 00:22:44,690
There we go.

421
00:22:44,690 --> 00:22:46,785
I can see admin login on
the VTY right there, and

422
00:22:46,785 --> 00:22:49,370
I'm coming from 192.168.0.100, right?

423
00:22:49,370 --> 00:22:52,770
So that's how we can get connected.

424
00:22:52,770 --> 00:22:55,450
Obviously the console is the fastest way.

425
00:22:55,450 --> 00:22:57,560
And the nice thing about the console
is you get all the debug

426
00:22:57,560 --> 00:23:01,140
logging automatically, but
this is a little more realistic.

427
00:23:01,140 --> 00:23:02,260
This is a little more real world.

428
00:23:02,260 --> 00:23:05,660
You'll SSH or Telnet into your routers,
hopefully not Telnet.

429
00:23:05,660 --> 00:23:08,380
With this, if I do debugs,
I don't get those messages right out.

430
00:23:08,380 --> 00:23:12,620
I have to do terminal monitor
to be able to see those,

431
00:23:12,620 --> 00:23:14,340
which would only work by enable.

432
00:23:14,340 --> 00:23:16,070
But this gives me that connectivity.

433
00:23:16,070 --> 00:23:18,260
Now I've got full access and
I'm ready to work in the system.

434
00:23:19,410 --> 00:23:20,040
All right.

435
00:23:20,040 --> 00:23:21,720
Well that's a pretty good
spot to stop this video.

436
00:23:21,720 --> 00:23:23,040
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

437
00:23:23,040 --> 00:23:25,610
Stay tuned.
We've got more videos coming up on

438
00:23:25,610 --> 00:23:28,430
how to do some of the more
advanced features inside of GNS3.

439
00:23:28,430 --> 00:23:31,260
There's a lot of cool
stuff under the hood.

440
00:23:31,260 --> 00:23:37,310
Hope you guys enjoyed it,
I'll see you next time.

441
00:23:37,310 --> 00:23:39,180
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Capturing Traffic In GNS3
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:08,140
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08,140 --> 00:00:13,310
One of the cooler features in GNS3
is integration with Wireshark.

3
00:00:13,310 --> 00:00:15,450
A lot of times when we configure
settings on our routers,

4
00:00:15,450 --> 00:00:17,720
we have to make certain
assumptions about the traffic.

5
00:00:17,720 --> 00:00:21,460
For example, let's say you set a VPN
tunnel up between two routers.

6
00:00:21,460 --> 00:00:24,960
How do you really know the traffic is
being encrypted that's being sent between

7
00:00:24,960 --> 00:00:25,870
the two routers?

8
00:00:25,870 --> 00:00:27,660
You've got physical
connectivity between them,

9
00:00:27,660 --> 00:00:29,900
so maybe traffic's going unencrypted.

10
00:00:29,900 --> 00:00:30,780
How do we know?

11
00:00:30,780 --> 00:00:32,810
Well, we can trust what
the routers tell us.

12
00:00:32,810 --> 00:00:36,210
But if we could attach a protocol
analyzer or a packet sniffer

13
00:00:36,210 --> 00:00:40,630
right here on the wire, we'd be able
to see the traffic on the wire and

14
00:00:40,630 --> 00:00:43,410
determine whether it was encrypted or
not, right.

15
00:00:43,410 --> 00:00:46,700
So that's one of the cool things
we have in real life land, right.

16
00:00:46,700 --> 00:00:50,010
On a physical network you can plug
a sniffer in, you can capture traffic.

17
00:00:50,010 --> 00:00:53,430
But in a virtual environment like
this that's not normally possible.

18
00:00:53,430 --> 00:00:55,820
Well in GNS3, it is.

19
00:00:55,820 --> 00:00:58,170
In our network,
at any point in our network,

20
00:00:58,170 --> 00:01:01,990
you can right-click on a cable and
choose Start Capturing.

21
00:01:01,990 --> 00:01:06,030
That'll start capturing traffic on that
line and storing it to a file, all right.

22
00:01:06,030 --> 00:01:06,530
I'm gonna do that.

23
00:01:06,530 --> 00:01:08,140
I'm just gonna hit, Start Capturing.

24
00:01:08,140 --> 00:01:10,680
It's gonna ask me which
interface I'm capturing for.

25
00:01:10,680 --> 00:01:13,750
If there's two routers here,
it's asking which interface I want.

26
00:01:13,750 --> 00:01:17,670
But in my case I've got a virtual switch
in between it so I only see the router.

27
00:01:17,670 --> 00:01:20,530
So I'll pick that one and
I'll say to start capturing it.

28
00:01:20,530 --> 00:01:22,620
Not much is different to me now, but

29
00:01:22,620 --> 00:01:28,220
in the background, any traffic being sent
over that line is now being captured.

30
00:01:28,220 --> 00:01:31,180
If the router's just sitting there,
I expect to see things like

31
00:01:31,180 --> 00:01:35,700
Cisco Discovery Protocol, CDP, or
RIP the Router Information Protocol.

32
00:01:35,700 --> 00:01:39,020
They're communicating over the line even
when the router is just sitting there.

33
00:01:39,020 --> 00:01:43,240
But other things, other activities that I
might send like my data, just the regular

34
00:01:43,240 --> 00:01:47,380
routed data, is gonna cross that
line also, and it's being captured.

35
00:01:47,380 --> 00:01:51,130
While the capture is running you can
right-click on the line again, and

36
00:01:51,130 --> 00:01:54,870
now we've got a new menu option
which is start WireShark.

37
00:01:54,870 --> 00:01:58,960
And if we start that up,
it's gonna launch up here and

38
00:01:58,960 --> 00:02:03,840
now I'm in Wireshark and it's showing
me what's going on, on that line.

39
00:02:03,840 --> 00:02:06,270
And as I look at it, sure enough,
there's some CDP traffic,

40
00:02:06,270 --> 00:02:08,840
Cisco Discovery Protocol right there.

41
00:02:08,840 --> 00:02:11,780
And, you know, I've got some
other loop back traffic going on.

42
00:02:11,780 --> 00:02:12,560
There's more CDP.

43
00:02:12,560 --> 00:02:16,230
CDP sends out a broadcast every,
I think it's every 30 seconds.

44
00:02:16,230 --> 00:02:18,320
Well, actually we can find out right here,
right.

45
00:02:18,320 --> 00:02:21,510
So I had one happen,
the time stamp was 8.37.

46
00:02:21,510 --> 00:02:23,370
The next one happened here at 41.98.

47
00:02:23,370 --> 00:02:29,520
So that's basically 30 seconds apart that
that's happening, it's a little bit more.

48
00:02:29,520 --> 00:02:32,060
CDP is doing it's stuff every 30 seconds.

49
00:02:32,060 --> 00:02:36,480
I'm running RIP on these systems also,
the Routing Information Protocol.

50
00:02:36,480 --> 00:02:38,640
RIP has a slightly longer timer though,
but

51
00:02:38,640 --> 00:02:42,110
I should see it anytime since I'm, oh
actually, I'm already seeing it, aren't I?

52
00:02:42,110 --> 00:02:45,185
These giant, highlighted in red,
where you can't miss them ones,

53
00:02:45,185 --> 00:02:46,790
that I'm not looking at.

54
00:02:46,790 --> 00:02:49,410
Here's rip though,
sending out it's communications.

55
00:02:49,410 --> 00:02:54,090
Rip version one, every so often, every
30 seconds, sending out its messages and

56
00:02:54,090 --> 00:02:55,110
announcements right.

57
00:02:55,110 --> 00:02:59,620
So I can see that traffic right there,
I can actually verify that it's happening.

58
00:02:59,620 --> 00:03:02,410
And now if I generate some other
like more exciting payload, right.

59
00:03:02,410 --> 00:03:04,840
Here I'll jump over to router one, and

60
00:03:04,840 --> 00:03:08,860
maybe on router one I
telnet to router two.

61
00:03:10,140 --> 00:03:16,480
So I'm gonna telnet over to router two,
and I'll log in and I'll get to work.

62
00:03:16,480 --> 00:03:18,360
I'm gonna get in here and
start doing my work.

63
00:03:21,077 --> 00:03:24,362
You know, maybe I'll assign
an IP address to an interface.

64
00:03:27,830 --> 00:03:30,300
And do a no shut down.

65
00:03:31,360 --> 00:03:32,560
And we'll add that to RIP.

66
00:03:32,560 --> 00:03:34,880
So this is just me doing my normal work.

67
00:03:36,840 --> 00:03:38,310
And, oh I'm class four right now.

68
00:03:38,310 --> 00:03:40,420
I guess we'll do the whole class B,
why not.

69
00:03:40,420 --> 00:03:42,450
All right, so I'm in here.

70
00:03:42,450 --> 00:03:43,540
I'm doing my work.

71
00:03:43,540 --> 00:03:45,889
I'm getting things setup all via Telnet.

72
00:03:45,889 --> 00:03:51,480
That Telnet session is going from router
one across this line to router two.

73
00:03:51,480 --> 00:03:53,320
So it should have all been captured.

74
00:03:53,320 --> 00:03:57,260
And if I go back to WireShark Looks
like you got a frame error.

75
00:03:57,260 --> 00:03:58,440
But it should have continued.

76
00:03:58,440 --> 00:03:59,670
Let's see if it actually, yeah it did.

77
00:03:59,670 --> 00:04:00,440
Good.

78
00:04:00,440 --> 00:04:03,660
One of my frames came in too large and
it made Wireshark get upset.

79
00:04:03,660 --> 00:04:04,650
But the rest of it.

80
00:04:04,650 --> 00:04:07,080
I can see that Telnet traffic right there.

81
00:04:07,080 --> 00:04:09,780
So that's me communicating
between those two routers.

82
00:04:09,780 --> 00:04:12,940
I can actually see what's
going on on the network

83
00:04:12,940 --> 00:04:15,740
versus having to trust that
it's happening that way.

84
00:04:15,740 --> 00:04:18,900
If I thought this was going over
a VPN tunnel, I know it's not now,

85
00:04:18,900 --> 00:04:20,190
because I can see it.

86
00:04:20,190 --> 00:04:23,560
And I could go and
reassemble that if I wanted to, and

87
00:04:23,560 --> 00:04:27,720
actually see the communication, or at
least what Wireshark got before it died.

88
00:04:27,720 --> 00:04:29,050
Yeah, it did, it actually died out.

89
00:04:29,050 --> 00:04:29,550
Hm.

90
00:04:31,090 --> 00:04:34,140
If it dies out like that you
can always close Wireshark.

91
00:04:34,140 --> 00:04:37,700
And if the capture is still running
you can just restart Wireshark and

92
00:04:37,700 --> 00:04:38,958
it'll normally get happy again.

93
00:04:38,958 --> 00:04:45,000
No, frame 93 two on, so I've got a bad
frame but basically it is working.

94
00:04:45,000 --> 00:04:46,290
It is capturing that data.

95
00:04:46,290 --> 00:04:49,290
I'd have to stop and start the capture
again to get around that, but

96
00:04:49,290 --> 00:04:52,360
that's how Wireshark works,
really neat visibility.

97
00:04:52,360 --> 00:04:55,240
We didn't have to change
any settings in Wireshark.

98
00:04:55,240 --> 00:04:58,460
Basically, GSN3 is pushing
that from the command line,

99
00:04:58,460 --> 00:05:02,920
it's telling Wireshark, hey, when you
launch, don't load from a network adapter,

100
00:05:02,920 --> 00:05:05,700
instead load from this file,
this file that I'm updating right now.

101
00:05:05,700 --> 00:05:08,480
So I'm gonna put my updates in the file,
you display it.

102
00:05:08,480 --> 00:05:12,880
So it's already doing that, it's showing
me the information all in real time.

103
00:05:12,880 --> 00:05:14,580
Down here you can actually see that file.

104
00:05:14,580 --> 00:05:18,220
It's a temporary file, it's stuck
in my user profile down here and

105
00:05:18,220 --> 00:05:20,600
it's just up running doing its thing.

106
00:05:23,760 --> 00:05:29,030
Yeah so a bad frame, so i did get a bad
frame if i just stop the capture.

107
00:05:29,030 --> 00:05:32,840
So ill just stop it and start it again,
that'll start an all new file and

108
00:05:32,840 --> 00:05:34,340
it'll get past that bad frame.

109
00:05:34,340 --> 00:05:35,270
And now.

110
00:05:35,270 --> 00:05:38,510
I can fire up Wireshark, and
will be watching it again and

111
00:05:38,510 --> 00:05:39,860
seeing all that action happen.

112
00:05:39,860 --> 00:05:45,000
So very exciting stuff right well,
this is incredibly exciting here but,

113
00:05:48,730 --> 00:05:51,990
when you're troubleshooting a protocol
where you're trying to see whether

114
00:05:51,990 --> 00:05:54,620
your RIP announcements are really
going out every thirty seconds,

115
00:05:54,620 --> 00:05:58,100
whether your rip announcements
are Rip version one doing unicast or

116
00:05:58,100 --> 00:06:01,280
rip version two doing multicast,
you'd see that here, right?

117
00:06:01,280 --> 00:06:04,880
When you go and find these packets, like
this one here, this is a RIP response,

118
00:06:04,880 --> 00:06:08,910
I can see that it came from router one,
192.168.0.1, and

119
00:06:08,910 --> 00:06:14,280
I can see the destination 255.255.255.255,
it broadcast out.

120
00:06:14,280 --> 00:06:16,950
RIP version one uses broadcast,
I can see it.

121
00:06:16,950 --> 00:06:21,270
If I go back to my routers,
I can switch them over to version 2 and

122
00:06:23,210 --> 00:06:26,340
I should see that change to multicasts.

123
00:06:26,340 --> 00:06:30,830
So if I go to router rip and throw in
a little version 2 action here, and

124
00:06:30,830 --> 00:06:32,110
I'll do the same on this side.

125
00:06:36,585 --> 00:06:39,540
All right so
those guys are now going to switch over.

126
00:06:39,540 --> 00:06:44,590
Now I assume that RIP is actually
doing the multicast like it says, but

127
00:06:44,590 --> 00:06:48,110
I don't have to assume anymore because I
can just jump over to Wireshark and watch.

128
00:06:50,020 --> 00:06:55,250
And now when I start to see RIP
communications going out, see how I've got

129
00:06:55,250 --> 00:07:00,530
broadcast here, broadcast here,
broadcast here, multicast here 224.0.0.9.

130
00:07:00,530 --> 00:07:05,730
I can see it switched and
its no longer RIP version one

131
00:07:05,730 --> 00:07:09,050
now its RIP version two, now things
are running the way that I want and

132
00:07:09,050 --> 00:07:12,230
I know their multicast because
I can see it right here.

133
00:07:12,230 --> 00:07:12,850
Right.

134
00:07:12,850 --> 00:07:15,720
That's the real power of
having Wireshark integrated.

135
00:07:15,720 --> 00:07:18,820
And you can save these, you can filter
them, you can do all sorts of crazy stuff.

136
00:07:18,820 --> 00:07:21,590
If you haven't watched our series
on how to use Wireshark you should

137
00:07:21,590 --> 00:07:22,490
check that out.

138
00:07:22,490 --> 00:07:25,490
I kind of run through all the different
stuff that you can do inside of Wireshark,

139
00:07:25,490 --> 00:07:27,300
it's a really powerful program.

140
00:07:27,300 --> 00:07:32,760
But from GNS3 it's just a great way to
see what traffic is going over the line.

141
00:07:32,760 --> 00:07:34,020
One work of advice though,

142
00:07:34,020 --> 00:07:38,540
when you're done with Wireshark always
remember to come in and stop the capture.

143
00:07:38,540 --> 00:07:42,270
If you don't stop the capture it's going
to continue to gather in the background.

144
00:07:42,270 --> 00:07:44,730
And that file will get larger and
larger and larger.

145
00:07:44,730 --> 00:07:47,600
You could potentially fill up your
hard drive if you forget about it and

146
00:07:47,600 --> 00:07:49,160
leave it running for a day or two.

147
00:07:49,160 --> 00:07:53,000
There's not gonna be a lot of data
moving over your virtual network but

148
00:07:53,000 --> 00:07:56,380
routing protocols, if you do dynamic
updates, they add up over time.

149
00:07:56,380 --> 00:07:58,620
You know that's all data
being sent across the line.

150
00:07:58,620 --> 00:08:02,660
Cisco discovery protocol, all those things
create a ton of chatter on the line.

151
00:08:03,760 --> 00:08:08,250
Alright but other than that using
Wireshark inside of GNS3, pretty easy.

152
00:08:08,250 --> 00:08:11,462
So definitely use that,
it's a cool feature.

153
00:08:11,462 --> 00:08:12,590
All right well stay tuned,

154
00:08:12,590 --> 00:08:15,960
we've got more episodes coming up
with addition information on GNS3.

155
00:08:15,960 --> 00:08:21,785
You know it's a powerful program, lot of
features there, so I hope to see you then.

156
00:08:21,785 --> 00:08:26,824
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Documenting Your Network
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,164
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03,164 --> 00:00:08,051
[SOUND] In GNS3, you can start to build

3
00:00:08,051 --> 00:00:12,183
some pretty complex networks.

4
00:00:12,183 --> 00:00:15,983
And as you lay them out in your map, you
can have more routers and more devices and

5
00:00:15,983 --> 00:00:17,910
it really does start to grow.

6
00:00:17,910 --> 00:00:21,610
So one of the more handy things we can
do is to create a network diagram.

7
00:00:21,610 --> 00:00:24,100
And I know a lot of people
use Microsoft Vizio or

8
00:00:24,100 --> 00:00:27,610
other software like that to create
their diagrams to have them handy, but

9
00:00:27,610 --> 00:00:31,170
there's actually some diagramming
functionality right inside of GNS3 that

10
00:00:31,170 --> 00:00:34,670
you can take advantage of and
you don't need separate software for it.

11
00:00:34,670 --> 00:00:36,390
So let me show you how that works.

12
00:00:36,390 --> 00:00:38,430
When I have networks like this, right?

13
00:00:38,430 --> 00:00:42,763
In between router one and
router two there's a switch, and

14
00:00:42,763 --> 00:00:46,678
this is the 192.168.0.0/24 subnet.

15
00:00:46,678 --> 00:00:49,680
Now, I know that because
I set up this router.

16
00:00:49,680 --> 00:00:52,820
But what if I want to share this
topology with someone else?

17
00:00:52,820 --> 00:00:55,440
They might not know the networks like
I do, cuz I'm the one who made it.

18
00:00:55,440 --> 00:00:56,908
It's easier for me to remember.

19
00:00:56,908 --> 00:00:58,830
If I wanna make it easier for

20
00:00:58,830 --> 00:01:02,820
them, I can add notations to
the screen to dictate that.

21
00:01:02,820 --> 00:01:05,850
You'll see up top where you can
add in things to your diagram,

22
00:01:05,850 --> 00:01:08,710
like circles, squares, and notes.

23
00:01:08,710 --> 00:01:12,705
Even pictures if you have some kind
of a network map or whatever that you

24
00:01:12,705 --> 00:01:15,120
wanna throw in there, maybe a map of
your building you wanna throw in there.

25
00:01:15,120 --> 00:01:16,062
You can do stuff like that.

26
00:01:16,062 --> 00:01:18,419
But I normally make use of circles and
notes.

27
00:01:18,419 --> 00:01:21,471
So, I'm gonna draw a circle, and

28
00:01:21,471 --> 00:01:26,342
when you draw a circle there's
not all that much to it.

29
00:01:26,342 --> 00:01:30,300
We kinda drag it around to
fit where it is we want it.

30
00:01:31,860 --> 00:01:34,040
We try and drag it around to
where we want it at least.

31
00:01:34,040 --> 00:01:35,965
I made mine a little bit on the big side.

32
00:01:35,965 --> 00:01:39,001
So I'm gonna draw it like that, okay?

33
00:01:39,001 --> 00:01:43,740
So there's my circle, and if you right
click on it, you can choose to set a style

34
00:01:43,740 --> 00:01:48,090
to it, duplicate it, raise it a layer,
lower it a layer, all right?

35
00:01:48,090 --> 00:01:50,680
These items all layer
on top of each other.

36
00:01:50,680 --> 00:01:54,070
See how the routers are sitting
on top of that dashed line?

37
00:01:54,070 --> 00:01:57,320
This circle just went
behind those routers.

38
00:01:57,320 --> 00:02:00,640
If I right click again,
I can choose to raise it a layer and

39
00:02:00,640 --> 00:02:03,330
now see how the circle's
on top of the routers?

40
00:02:03,330 --> 00:02:06,030
So you can build this where you've
got things several layers deep and

41
00:02:06,030 --> 00:02:08,680
you dictate which order
the objects are displayed in.

42
00:02:08,680 --> 00:02:12,975
I want my circle to be all the way in
the back, and I'm gonna change its style.

43
00:02:12,975 --> 00:02:16,307
The style's gonna let us change the line,
as well as the coloring.

44
00:02:16,307 --> 00:02:20,130
I want the color,
well the color right now is black.

45
00:02:20,130 --> 00:02:22,330
That's the dashed line
around the outside is black.

46
00:02:22,330 --> 00:02:25,130
That's exactly what I want,
so I'm gonna leave that be.

47
00:02:25,130 --> 00:02:27,690
The font would be text if I
was throwing it in there.

48
00:02:27,690 --> 00:02:29,892
The border color,
I can see that one's black.

49
00:02:29,892 --> 00:02:32,810
Actually, you know what?
I've got it backwards, don't I?

50
00:02:32,810 --> 00:02:34,420
The select color here is the inside.

51
00:02:34,420 --> 00:02:36,700
I'm gonna make it like a light green.

52
00:02:36,700 --> 00:02:37,750
Ew, that's a terrible green.

53
00:02:37,750 --> 00:02:38,250
Let's try that one.

54
00:02:39,710 --> 00:02:40,246
There we go.

55
00:02:40,246 --> 00:02:41,689
So, see how it just turned light green?

56
00:02:41,689 --> 00:02:45,700
Because that's the color I chose
up here when I did Select Color.

57
00:02:45,700 --> 00:02:46,870
It's got green.

58
00:02:46,870 --> 00:02:49,040
The border is black and that's fine.

59
00:02:49,040 --> 00:02:50,070
That's what I want.

60
00:02:50,070 --> 00:02:53,090
And for the font, well I'm not
putting any text on it just yet.

61
00:02:53,090 --> 00:02:55,540
I'll do that in a minute,
so I'll leave that be.

62
00:02:55,540 --> 00:02:57,722
I've got the border width and
the border style.

63
00:02:57,722 --> 00:03:00,680
I'm gonna make my border just
a little bit thicker and

64
00:03:00,680 --> 00:03:02,450
I'm gonna change it to a solid line,
all right?

65
00:03:02,450 --> 00:03:07,140
And when I say okay,
apparently it didn't like that.

66
00:03:07,140 --> 00:03:09,090
Let me go back in here and
double check that.

67
00:03:09,090 --> 00:03:11,120
Maybe that width going a little too high.

68
00:03:12,490 --> 00:03:14,850
But my select color, oh,
it went back to black.

69
00:03:14,850 --> 00:03:17,160
All right, well,
let's put it back to green.

70
00:03:17,160 --> 00:03:17,920
There we go.

71
00:03:17,920 --> 00:03:22,041
Now I've got a nice green circle right
there, which I can use to denote a subnet,

72
00:03:22,041 --> 00:03:22,662
all right?

73
00:03:22,662 --> 00:03:27,860
So the circle's got that and
now I can go up to my notes and

74
00:03:27,860 --> 00:03:35,090
I can stick a note right here,
and I can say 192.168.0.0/24.

75
00:03:35,090 --> 00:03:39,370
That's that subnet right there and
now I can remember that's what it is.

76
00:03:39,370 --> 00:03:42,780
And if somebody were to log in and
I share this with them, they would see it.

77
00:03:42,780 --> 00:03:44,270
Now I do have a little problem.

78
00:03:44,270 --> 00:03:45,960
My circle is on top of the link.

79
00:03:45,960 --> 00:03:48,770
I can't see the links
between my routers anymore.

80
00:03:48,770 --> 00:03:51,319
So I'm gonna continue to hit lower layer.

81
00:03:52,890 --> 00:03:53,840
There we go.

82
00:03:53,840 --> 00:03:56,210
Until it's back and
now the links are on top of it.

83
00:03:56,210 --> 00:03:57,720
Green might not have
been the best color here,

84
00:03:57,720 --> 00:03:59,420
cuz now it's hard to see the link lights.

85
00:03:59,420 --> 00:04:02,430
So, you might have to mess with
it a little bit until you find

86
00:04:02,430 --> 00:04:05,590
the proper color sequence or
whatever that you wanna use.

87
00:04:05,590 --> 00:04:07,310
Maybe we'll go brown.

88
00:04:07,310 --> 00:04:08,370
There we are.

89
00:04:08,370 --> 00:04:10,670
So I've got it laid out right there,
all right?

90
00:04:10,670 --> 00:04:14,720
And I can continue to document my network
this way, adding circles or squares,

91
00:04:14,720 --> 00:04:15,540
or whatever.

92
00:04:15,540 --> 00:04:21,450
Maybe I wanna do a square over here
to denote this network, and so

93
00:04:21,450 --> 00:04:28,030
I'll make it a little bit bigger, and have
it come over here and contact Router 1.

94
00:04:28,030 --> 00:04:30,180
And then I'll change its style,
just like I did on the other one,

95
00:04:30,180 --> 00:04:34,990
maybe I'll make this one a dark blue,
right?

96
00:04:34,990 --> 00:04:36,190
And let me fix that border.

97
00:04:38,720 --> 00:04:41,330
It says that the border is solid but
it sure doesn't look like it.

98
00:04:42,530 --> 00:04:44,260
There it goes, now it's solid.

99
00:04:44,260 --> 00:04:47,310
I've got that whole problem of
covering the links again, so

100
00:04:47,310 --> 00:04:48,259
I'm gonna lower it a layer.

101
00:04:49,970 --> 00:04:51,481
Okay, so there it is, it's behind.

102
00:04:51,481 --> 00:04:56,805
And if I go and
stick a note on top of this one I can say,

103
00:04:56,805 --> 00:05:02,371
this is the 192.168.1.0/24 network.

104
00:05:02,371 --> 00:05:05,610
Now, I do have a little problem here
that I can barely read that text.

105
00:05:05,610 --> 00:05:09,620
So, I might wanna change the style of
that text to be a different color.

106
00:05:09,620 --> 00:05:12,110
So, the font is fine.

107
00:05:12,110 --> 00:05:14,590
I guess I could make it a bigger font,
make it easier to read there, but for

108
00:05:14,590 --> 00:05:16,210
the color, let me make that white.

109
00:05:16,210 --> 00:05:18,000
That should stand out a little better.

110
00:05:18,000 --> 00:05:18,790
There we go.

111
00:05:18,790 --> 00:05:22,430
Now I can easily read that and see it,
and tell it that's what that network is.

112
00:05:22,430 --> 00:05:25,270
Or I could have just picked a better
color, that blue is pretty harsh.

113
00:05:25,270 --> 00:05:28,020
So [LAUGH] you can manipulate
this however you want.

114
00:05:28,020 --> 00:05:30,080
Kinda customize it, get things set.

115
00:05:30,080 --> 00:05:33,728
And then once you've got it in place,
now it's really easy to just

116
00:05:33,728 --> 00:05:38,369
visually look at this and say, okay,
that's the 192.168.00 network.

117
00:05:38,369 --> 00:05:41,275
This is the 192.168.1.0 network.

118
00:05:41,275 --> 00:05:42,839
It's all right there.

119
00:05:42,839 --> 00:05:46,007
I don't have to login to the router and
do a show IP interface brief or

120
00:05:46,007 --> 00:05:48,800
anything like that to
find out those networks.

121
00:05:48,800 --> 00:05:52,230
You can make use of this,
it's all saved with your topology.

122
00:05:52,230 --> 00:05:54,310
So when you open up this
network again later on,

123
00:05:54,310 --> 00:05:57,690
it'll all be laid out just like this and
it works out really well.

124
00:05:57,690 --> 00:06:01,770
And if you wanna print it out to have it
like on a piece of paper next to you,

125
00:06:01,770 --> 00:06:05,240
you can use the camera button
up here to take a snapshot, and

126
00:06:05,240 --> 00:06:08,680
when you do that it'll
save it as a PNG file.

127
00:06:08,680 --> 00:06:10,980
So let me just do that here
I'll save it to my desktop.

128
00:06:10,980 --> 00:06:16,130
And now I can go into my desktop and

129
00:06:16,130 --> 00:06:19,400
find that topology file I just dumped and
there it is.

130
00:06:19,400 --> 00:06:20,590
There's my network diagram.

131
00:06:20,590 --> 00:06:22,570
I can print that out on a piece of paper.

132
00:06:22,570 --> 00:06:26,350
And now I've got it easy to work with as
I get in there and work with my network.

133
00:06:26,350 --> 00:06:27,880
So, very handy feature.

134
00:06:27,880 --> 00:06:30,885
We don't need separate software
like Vizio to do this.

135
00:06:30,885 --> 00:06:33,480
It's not the most advanced
stuff in the world.

136
00:06:33,480 --> 00:06:35,770
I can't put custom objects in there.

137
00:06:35,770 --> 00:06:36,880
If you wanted to do a custom object,

138
00:06:36,880 --> 00:06:40,470
you'd have to have it as an image and
bring it in using that image button.

139
00:06:40,470 --> 00:06:43,540
So I can hit that and bring in items.

140
00:06:43,540 --> 00:06:45,410
That can be kinda handy sometimes.

141
00:06:45,410 --> 00:06:49,420
For example, maybe you're
building a lab for somebody and

142
00:06:49,420 --> 00:06:52,350
you want them to work in this router and
this switch, but

143
00:06:52,350 --> 00:06:54,030
you don't want them to work
in any of this other stuff.

144
00:06:54,030 --> 00:06:55,230
So you may not even include these,

145
00:06:55,230 --> 00:06:58,210
you might just put a picture
that shows these items, and

146
00:06:58,210 --> 00:07:01,830
then you add your other routers on top of
it to make it look like they were there.

147
00:07:01,830 --> 00:07:06,480
So, there's different things like that you
can do to manipulate the diagrams, but for

148
00:07:06,480 --> 00:07:07,510
the most part that's it.

149
00:07:07,510 --> 00:07:10,900
So, there's some good
documentation features in there.

150
00:07:10,900 --> 00:07:11,720
Make use of them, right?

151
00:07:11,720 --> 00:07:15,670
They're pretty handy and they'll help you
keep track of your networks a lot better.

152
00:07:15,670 --> 00:07:16,980
All right,
hope you guys enjoyed that video.

153
00:07:16,980 --> 00:07:18,075
Stay tuned.
We've got more

154
00:07:18,075 --> 00:07:20,070
GNS3 information in our other videos.

155
00:07:20,070 --> 00:07:21,439
Be sure to check out our whole library,
right?

156
00:07:21,439 --> 00:07:23,918
We go through the all the different
features and what you can do.

157
00:07:23,918 --> 00:07:26,559
It's powerful software, so
there's a lot of features.

158
00:07:26,559 --> 00:07:29,607
All right,
hope to see you in the other videos.

159
00:07:29,607 --> 00:07:35,089
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Saving Your Configuration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,591
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,591 --> 00:00:11,898
All right, you might be asking yourself,
why did I just hit play on a video that's

3
00:00:11,898 --> 00:00:14,300
gonna tell me how to
save my configuration.

4
00:00:14,300 --> 00:00:18,150
Everybody knows how to go to file and
save, this is the dumbest video ever.

5
00:00:18,150 --> 00:00:19,710
Well, unfortunately,

6
00:00:19,710 --> 00:00:23,380
there are some little quirks to how we
save our configurations inside of GNS3.

7
00:00:23,380 --> 00:00:27,110
So I wanted to do a video that
kind of highlighted some of that.

8
00:00:27,110 --> 00:00:30,060
Yes, you're right,
when you develop a topology in GNS3,

9
00:00:30,060 --> 00:00:33,190
you can just go to File > Save Project,
right.

10
00:00:33,190 --> 00:00:37,880
And that will save your project and
store it on the hard drive.

11
00:00:37,880 --> 00:00:41,420
It does give you a little warning,
it's gonna stop all the devices and

12
00:00:41,420 --> 00:00:42,240
back them up.

13
00:00:42,240 --> 00:00:45,000
So I'll go ahead and
say yes to that, and let it backup.

14
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:48,351
I give it a project name, so
I'll call this my Show Topology and

15
00:00:48,351 --> 00:00:52,920
it's gonna back it up to a directory
inside of my user folder.

16
00:00:52,920 --> 00:00:54,600
It does have a few options.

17
00:00:54,600 --> 00:00:58,040
I can save the NVRAM inside of the device.

18
00:00:58,040 --> 00:00:59,940
Now what's in the NVRAM?

19
00:00:59,940 --> 00:01:01,670
Our start up configs, right?

20
00:01:01,670 --> 00:01:03,300
If you don't save the start up config,

21
00:01:03,300 --> 00:01:08,340
what you're really backing up is just
your topology, this network layout.

22
00:01:08,340 --> 00:01:10,940
If I were to hit save
with how it is right now.

23
00:01:10,940 --> 00:01:15,900
When I restore my system, when I open up
GNS3 and I open up this project my routers

24
00:01:15,900 --> 00:01:19,100
will have no configuration, they'll
start up with default configurations.

25
00:01:19,100 --> 00:01:22,860
So, I need to make sure
that I save NVRAM so

26
00:01:22,860 --> 00:01:25,470
that I get the start up configurations so
that way when I boot them back up they'll

27
00:01:25,470 --> 00:01:29,020
be where I left them off as long as I
remembered to save my configuration.

28
00:01:29,020 --> 00:01:32,550
That's quirk number one we
need to remember to do that

29
00:01:32,550 --> 00:01:34,930
otherwise we'll lose our router configs.

30
00:01:34,930 --> 00:01:38,750
Some of the other options you have here,
things like unbase images when saving.

31
00:01:39,830 --> 00:01:42,180
When you save an image, especially for

32
00:01:42,180 --> 00:01:47,070
the virtual machines that use QEMU,
they can be tied to a master image.

33
00:01:47,070 --> 00:01:49,980
If you choose to unbase it,
it'll make copies of that master so

34
00:01:49,980 --> 00:01:52,820
that it's easier to move this
project to other computers.

35
00:01:52,820 --> 00:01:56,180
If you’re not using any of the QEMU
stuff you don’t have to worry about it.

36
00:01:56,180 --> 00:02:00,640
If you’re using several routers
of the same iOS, this will create

37
00:02:00,640 --> 00:02:04,970
multiple copies that iOS, but
again that’s not necessarily a big deal.

38
00:02:04,970 --> 00:02:07,655
And then we’ve got Save capture traffic.

39
00:02:07,655 --> 00:02:11,595
If you're running Wire Shark, and doing
traffic captures of the network passing

40
00:02:11,595 --> 00:02:14,335
across the line,
the default is not to save that stuff.

41
00:02:14,335 --> 00:02:17,035
And so, if you want to, you can check that
off, but normally we just want to make

42
00:02:17,035 --> 00:02:21,515
sure we check save NVRAMs, and
we hit OK, and now it's backed up.

43
00:02:21,515 --> 00:02:23,735
All my routers stopped, but
that's not the end of the world.

44
00:02:23,735 --> 00:02:26,390
I can always start them right back up,
and off we go.

45
00:02:26,390 --> 00:02:30,590
Okay, notice down here it says
exporting Router 2 configuration,

46
00:02:30,590 --> 00:02:32,380
exporting Router 1 configuration.

47
00:02:32,380 --> 00:02:35,700
So it did dump the configs
to a text file so

48
00:02:35,700 --> 00:02:38,390
that it can load them back up again,
all right.

49
00:02:38,390 --> 00:02:39,980
Let me give you one
word of warning though.

50
00:02:39,980 --> 00:02:44,410
I'm gonna start this up, and
apparently it wasn't happy with that.

51
00:02:47,640 --> 00:02:49,110
Looks like it didn't cleanly stop.

52
00:02:49,110 --> 00:02:50,890
I hate it when that happens.

53
00:02:50,890 --> 00:02:54,690
If you ever have that happen when
the routers don't cleanly stop right,

54
00:02:54,690 --> 00:02:58,550
it's usually tied to the fact that I had
console windows open when it shut down.

55
00:02:58,550 --> 00:03:00,440
I should have closed those but I didn't.

56
00:03:00,440 --> 00:03:01,730
If that ever happens,

57
00:03:01,730 --> 00:03:06,510
the best thing to do is to get out of
GNS3 It's gonna ask me if I wanna save.

58
00:03:06,510 --> 00:03:08,430
I'll go ahead and let it save, all right.

59
00:03:08,430 --> 00:03:11,710
And then, check in your Task Manager
to make sure it's not still running.

60
00:03:11,710 --> 00:03:15,190
Now it's not gonna be listed as GNS3,
remember the emulator under the hood is

61
00:03:15,190 --> 00:03:17,940
called Dynamips, so
that's what I need to look for.

62
00:03:17,940 --> 00:03:21,620
I'm just gonna look and see if I have any
processes called Dynamips, and I don't.

63
00:03:21,620 --> 00:03:23,720
And so now I can fire it up and
get a clean start.

64
00:03:25,190 --> 00:03:28,760
So, I'll fire it back up, and
I'm gonna open up my topology.

65
00:03:28,760 --> 00:03:30,180
Well, after I get passed my tip screen.

66
00:03:30,180 --> 00:03:34,930
So, I'm gonna choose to open a product,
and I'll pick that show topology that I

67
00:03:34,930 --> 00:03:37,670
just did a moment ago, and
it's gonna load that one up.

68
00:03:38,742 --> 00:03:41,610
All right, so here's my topology,
just like I like it.

69
00:03:41,610 --> 00:03:44,950
Now, let me start up Router 1,
when I start it up and

70
00:03:44,950 --> 00:03:48,160
connect to it,
it should have my configuration.

71
00:03:49,220 --> 00:03:52,210
Now I say should,
because sometimes it doesn't.

72
00:03:52,210 --> 00:03:53,700
I have seen this more than once,

73
00:03:53,700 --> 00:03:57,222
where even though I told it
to save the NVRAM, it didn't.

74
00:03:57,222 --> 00:04:00,140
So we'll find out here in just a moment,
as soon this is done booting up,

75
00:04:00,140 --> 00:04:03,010
whether or
not it's got my proper config on there.

76
00:04:03,010 --> 00:04:06,390
So here it's going,
I had assigned some ip addresses to it.

77
00:04:06,390 --> 00:04:09,390
I had turned on the rip
routing protocol so

78
00:04:09,390 --> 00:04:13,030
I expect to see that in my running
configurations when I go in here.

79
00:04:13,030 --> 00:04:15,400
If I don't see it I know it didn't get it,
but it did.

80
00:04:15,400 --> 00:04:21,080
I've got my ip addresses right there and
I've got my rip configuration right there.

81
00:04:21,080 --> 00:04:24,250
So yup, it's got my configuration,
this router is up and healthy.

82
00:04:25,270 --> 00:04:26,041
All right,

83
00:04:26,041 --> 00:04:30,830
now more than once I've had GNS3 not
save my start up config like it said.

84
00:04:32,200 --> 00:04:34,460
If it happens to you,
there's a quick way to check and

85
00:04:34,460 --> 00:04:35,960
see if that's about to happen.

86
00:04:35,960 --> 00:04:40,580
Before you close GNS3, before, at the end
of the day you hit save and before you

87
00:04:40,580 --> 00:04:45,410
close it, what I like to do is right click
on a router, like I'll use Router 2 here.

88
00:04:45,410 --> 00:04:50,120
And when you right click on it, you'll see
an entry in here that says startup config.

89
00:04:50,120 --> 00:04:51,750
You can click on that, and

90
00:04:51,750 --> 00:04:56,480
it will show you what GNS3 thinks
the startup config is going to be.

91
00:04:56,480 --> 00:05:01,770
If it's blank, that means GNS3
didn't actually back it up.

92
00:05:01,770 --> 00:05:03,250
So it's a real quick easy way to check.

93
00:05:03,250 --> 00:05:05,357
If you come in here and
it looks like this.

94
00:05:05,357 --> 00:05:10,450
That's an easy way to let you know,
this router, it's not

95
00:05:10,450 --> 00:05:15,610
actually got its config and the way you
fix that, is you start the router up.

96
00:05:15,610 --> 00:05:18,550
It needs to be running and
you go to Startup Config,

97
00:05:18,550 --> 00:05:21,820
and this will be blank, right?

98
00:05:21,820 --> 00:05:24,370
And you just hit load config from NVRAM.

99
00:05:24,370 --> 00:05:28,240
That'll force it to go to the router,
get the config out of NVRAM, and

100
00:05:28,240 --> 00:05:29,200
throw it right here.

101
00:05:29,200 --> 00:05:31,880
This is what's gonna be backed
up to that file, all right.

102
00:05:31,880 --> 00:05:36,079
So if you ever see that being blank,
that's your warning sign.

103
00:05:36,079 --> 00:05:37,280
That's your warning sign to say,
for whatever reason,

104
00:05:37,280 --> 00:05:41,825
GNS3 didn't pick up the config and
it happens more often than you'd think.

105
00:05:41,825 --> 00:05:43,625
It actually happened to
me before this show,

106
00:05:43,625 --> 00:05:46,055
which is why I'm filming this
episode in the first place.

107
00:05:46,055 --> 00:05:50,270
So it is something that happens and
I just wanted you to have a heads up.

108
00:05:50,270 --> 00:05:53,650
Otherwise, once you save it,
your topology has been backed up.

109
00:05:53,650 --> 00:06:01,420
The most important part of your
topology is the topology file itself.

110
00:06:01,420 --> 00:06:06,140
You'll have a file that ends in .net,
so if I go in here to my projects and

111
00:06:06,140 --> 00:06:07,035
show topology.

112
00:06:07,035 --> 00:06:12,390
Topology.net, that's the main topology
file and it's just a text file.

113
00:06:12,390 --> 00:06:15,890
If you edit it like I'll
open it with Wordpad.

114
00:06:17,695 --> 00:06:18,575
Do I have something good?

115
00:06:18,575 --> 00:06:19,305
Yes, sublime text.

116
00:06:19,305 --> 00:06:20,845
We'll open it with that.

117
00:06:20,845 --> 00:06:25,245
There, it's just a text file, and it lays
out the various systems that are on here.

118
00:06:25,245 --> 00:06:27,865
So, what iOS file I'm loading,

119
00:06:27,865 --> 00:06:32,825
what interfaces it's got, what they're
mapped to, if I have a virtual switch.

120
00:06:32,825 --> 00:06:36,385
There's router 1, router 2,
and all of that is laid out.

121
00:06:36,385 --> 00:06:40,810
Here's my notes that I added to
the screen and even the circle and

122
00:06:40,810 --> 00:06:44,770
square they'll be in here too with
their little text coordinates so

123
00:06:44,770 --> 00:06:46,710
it knows where to draw them on the screen.

124
00:06:46,710 --> 00:06:48,500
It's all just stored right
here in this text file.

125
00:06:48,500 --> 00:06:50,790
Nothing too terribly special about it, but

126
00:06:50,790 --> 00:06:54,790
you'll see other folders too like
where the configs are stored.

127
00:06:54,790 --> 00:06:55,960
And those are just text files.

128
00:06:55,960 --> 00:06:59,580
We can open those with
any kind of text editor.

129
00:07:01,250 --> 00:07:04,300
So here's router one's config
laid out right here for me.

130
00:07:04,300 --> 00:07:05,290
I can look at it.

131
00:07:05,290 --> 00:07:06,330
You can even edit it and

132
00:07:06,330 --> 00:07:09,568
the next time you fire up the router's it
will load this in as the start up config.

133
00:07:09,568 --> 00:07:11,750
So it's kinda neat to be able to do that.

134
00:07:11,750 --> 00:07:16,180
So saving your configurations not that
big of a deal File > Save Project.

135
00:07:16,180 --> 00:07:19,460
Make sure you tick off that check mark
that says save the NVRAM though if you

136
00:07:19,460 --> 00:07:23,160
want to save your start up configs
otherwise they will get lost, all right.

137
00:07:23,160 --> 00:07:25,390
So just quick word to the wise.

138
00:07:25,390 --> 00:07:28,475
One last thing I wanna mention is you
do have a handy little button up here

139
00:07:28,475 --> 00:07:30,185
with two arrows on it.

140
00:07:30,185 --> 00:07:31,635
If you click on that,

141
00:07:31,635 --> 00:07:36,203
that let's you extract your
configs to a different directory.

142
00:07:36,203 --> 00:07:40,125
If you wanna back up the configs alone,
not the whole topology, just the configs,

143
00:07:40,125 --> 00:07:45,485
you can use this, and you can extract
those, or import configs from a directory.

144
00:07:45,485 --> 00:07:49,220
You might have one topology,
we have ten different labs for it.

145
00:07:49,220 --> 00:07:52,680
So ten different sets of configs you
might wanna start up with and so

146
00:07:52,680 --> 00:07:56,660
you would import your configs from a
directory and specify that directory would

147
00:07:56,660 --> 00:07:59,360
load all the configs and
now you're ready to start that lab.

148
00:07:59,360 --> 00:08:01,420
I did that when I was studying for
some of my exams.

149
00:08:01,420 --> 00:08:05,880
I built one very complex topology, but I
had a bunch of different sets of configs I

150
00:08:05,880 --> 00:08:08,210
would load based on what
lab I wanted to do.

151
00:08:08,210 --> 00:08:12,940
So kinda a neat functionality
there using the two arrow button.

152
00:08:12,940 --> 00:08:15,160
That'll do all the configs for
the routers.

153
00:08:15,160 --> 00:08:16,910
You can do it on an individual router too.

154
00:08:16,910 --> 00:08:19,630
If you right click on it, you've got a few
options in there to be able to mess around

155
00:08:19,630 --> 00:08:21,990
with it if you go under configure.

156
00:08:21,990 --> 00:08:27,610
But for the most part, we do it as a whole
cuz it's our full lab environment.

157
00:08:27,610 --> 00:08:29,750
All right well that's about it for saving.

158
00:08:29,750 --> 00:08:34,040
I know a whole video on something as
simple as saving but it is important.

159
00:08:34,040 --> 00:08:36,020
So I hoped that helped you guys.

160
00:08:36,020 --> 00:08:38,410
Stay tuned we've got other videos on GNS3.

161
00:08:38,410 --> 00:08:41,200
If you haven't watched the other ones,
make sure you check them out.

162
00:08:41,200 --> 00:08:44,510
We've got a lot of features to cover and
they're all kinda covered in this section.

163
00:08:44,510 --> 00:08:45,430
So take advantage of that.

164
00:08:45,430 --> 00:08:45,990
They are there for you.
